questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding HYPER-IgM syndrome is incorrect? questions.text: A genetic counselor discusses the principles of genetic screening with a group of medical students. Which of the following statements correctly describe genetic screening? Genetic screening precisely defines the risk of an individual passing a genetic disorder to their offspring. Genetic screening tests generally provide more accurate results than diagnostic genetic tests. Genetic screening often involves the use of genetic mapping to identify gene mutations. Genetic screening procedures usually involve invasive techniques.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Genetic screening is essential for estimating the risk of transmitting genetic disorders and typically involves specific tests, some of which may be invasive. Unlike diagnostic tests, which provide definitive results, screening tests assess potential risks, guiding further diagnostic follow-ups when necessary. Understanding these distinctions is crucial for effectively communicating the purposes and expectations of genetic screening in clinical settings.
  • ➤ Genetic screening is essential for estimating the risk of transmitting genetic disorders and typically involves specific tests, some of which may be invasive. Unlike diagnostic tests, which provide definitive results, screening tests assess potential risks, guiding further diagnostic follow-ups when necessary.
  • ➤ Understanding these distinctions is crucial for effectively communicating the purposes and expectations of genetic screening in clinical settings.

questions.text: The pathway from the intestinal lumen to the circulating blood for short-chain fatty acids (<10 carbon atoms) is?

options.text: Space between mucosal cells → lymphatic duct → systemic venous blood

questions.text: A woman whose blood type is A, Rh positive, and a man whose blood type is B, Rh positive, come to the clinic with a 3-year-old girl whose blood type is O, Rh negative. What can be said about the relationship of these two adults to this child?

options.label: A
options.text: The woman can be the child’s natural mother, but the man cannot be the natural father

options.label: B
options.text: The man can be the child’s natural father, but the woman cannot be the natural mother

options.label: D
options.text: This couple can be the natural parents of this child

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) This couple can be the natural parents of this child

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blood type inheritance follows Mendelian genetics where the ABO system is determined by codominant alleles , and the Rh factor follows a dominant-recessive pattern . Parents with blood types A and B can have a child with blood type O if they carry the O allele . Similarly, two Rh+ parents can have an Rh- child if both are heterozygous ( Rh+/Rh- ).
  • ➤ Blood type inheritance follows Mendelian genetics where the ABO system is determined by codominant alleles , and the Rh factor follows a dominant-recessive pattern .
  • ➤ Mendelian genetics
  • ➤ ABO system

  • ➤ dominant-recessive pattern
  • ➤ Parents with blood types A and B can have a child with blood type O if they carry the O allele . Similarly, two Rh+ parents can have an Rh- child if both are heterozygous ( Rh+/Rh- ).
  • ➤ blood types A and B
  • ➤ blood type O
  • ➤ O allele
  • ➤ Rh+ parents

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was trying to pour water from a glass jar into his cup but the glass jar slipped off his fingers and fell down. As he tried to gather the broken pieces of glass, he noticed that one of those glass pieces deeply pierced the skin on the front of his right wrist. On examination, a small wound was present in the front of his forearm and the palmaris longus tendon had been severed. The thumb was laterally rotated and adducted, and the boy was unable to oppose his thumb to the other fingers. There was loss of skin sensation over the lateral half of the palm and the palmar aspect of the lateral three and a half fingers. The following facts concerning this patient are correct except.

options.label: A
options.text: Adduction of thumb is caused by adductor pollicis that is supplied by ulnar nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Opposition of thumb is produced by opponens pollicis that is innervated by median nerve

options.label: C
options.text: The median nerve lies in the interval between the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis and the palmaris longus just proximal to the wrist joint

options.label: D
options.text: Sensory loss of the distal part of the dorsal surfaces of the lateral three and a half fingers was present

questions.correct_answer: C. The median nerve lies in the interval between the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis and the palmaris longus just proximal to the wrist joint
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The median nerve lies in the interval between the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis and the palmaris longus just proximal to the wrist joint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The median nerve does not lie between the tendons of the flexor digitorum superficialis and the palmaris longus. Just proximal to the wrist joint, the median nerve is actually located more medially, typically lying just lateral to the tendon of the flexor carpi radialis and under the flexor retinaculum. The palmaris longus, when present, tends to be more superficial and median to the median nerve.
  • ➤ The median nerve does not lie between the tendons of the flexor digitorum superficialis and the palmaris longus.
  • ➤ Just proximal to the wrist joint, the median nerve is actually located more medially, typically lying just lateral to the tendon of the flexor carpi radialis and under the flexor retinaculum.
  • ➤ The palmaris longus, when present, tends to be more superficial and median to the median nerve.

Cariprazine has also been shown to be superior to first (D2 antagonists) and second-generation (5HT2A antagonists) antipsychotics for the improvement of negative symptoms of schizophrenia.

Women with PCOS commonly present with unilateral large ovarian cysts. Hirsutism is a common clinical feature of PCOS. OCPs (Oral Contraceptive Pills) are used as a treatment option in PCOS. PCOS is characterized by a high FSH/LH ratio.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 3, and 4 are true

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PCOS is a metabolic and reproductive disorder associated with insulin resistance, hyperandrogenism, and irregular ovulation. Key features include menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, acne, and an increased risk of diabetes. OCPs are the mainstay of treatment for regulating menstrual cycles and managing androgen excess symptoms. Unlike ovarian cysts, PCOS is characterized by multiple small follicular cysts rather than a large unilateral cyst.
  • ➤ PCOS is a metabolic and reproductive disorder associated with insulin resistance, hyperandrogenism, and irregular ovulation.
  • ➤ Key features include menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, acne, and an increased risk of diabetes.
  • ➤ OCPs are the mainstay of treatment for regulating menstrual cycles and managing androgen excess symptoms.
  • ➤ Unlike ovarian cysts, PCOS is characterized by multiple small follicular cysts rather than a large unilateral cyst.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding EBV-associated malignancies is incorrect? EBV is associated with endemic Burkitt's lymphoma, particularly in African children. EBV plays a role in the pathogenesis of Hodgkin's lymphoma, especially the mixed cellularity subtype. EBV has a well-established role in the development of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. EBV is the primary cause of T-cell leukemia in the Caribbean and Japan. Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma has been reported in association with EBV, particularly in immunocompromised patients.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Only 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is associated with several malignancies including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, but it is not linked to T-cell leukemia, which is caused by HTLV-1.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic hepatitis B infection presents for routine follow-up. His liver function tests are stable, and he has no signs of cirrhosis. Due to increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), he undergoes periodic imaging surveillance. Which of the following best explains the underlying mechanism by which hepatitis B increases this patient’s risk of liver cancer?

options.label: B
options.text: Sustained hepatocyte regeneration due to chronic inflammation

options.label: C
options.text: Production of viral RNA that integrates with host DNA

options.label: D
options.text: Upregulation of tumor suppressor genes in hepatocytes

questions.correct_answer: B. Sustained hepatocyte regeneration due to chronic inflammation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sustained hepatocyte regeneration due to chronic inflammation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatitis B promotes hepatocellular carcinoma primarily through chronic liver inflammation that leads to sustained hepatocyte regeneration. This ongoing cell turnover increases the likelihood of genetic mutations and malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with multiple erythematous papules and comedones on her cheeks and forehead. She reports that the lesions started gradually over the past year and worsen during her menstrual cycle. She also mentions using over-the-counter face creams, but without significant improvement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acne vulgaris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acne vulgaris is a common skin disorder of adolescence, characterized by comedones, inflammatory papules, and pustules. It typically affects the face, chest, and back and may worsen with hormonal changes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with irregular menstrual cycles and heavy menstrual bleeding. A histopathological examination of the endometrial biopsy is as shown in the image below. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Progesterone therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In reproductive-age women with simple endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, cyclical or continuous progesterone therapy is the treatment of choice to prevent progression to atypical hyperplasia or endometrial carcinoma. Estrogen is contraindicated in this setting.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus and known diabetic nephropathy (eGFR: 35 mL/min/1.73m²) is scheduled for imaging to evaluate for suspected renal artery stenosis. His current medications include metformin, lisinopril, and furosemide. To minimize the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN), several strategies are considered. Which of the following approaches is not considered effective in reducing the risk of CIN in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Using iso-osmolar contrast agents during the procedure

options.label: B
options.text: Ensuring adequate intravenous volume expansion before the study

options.label: C
options.text: Withholding medications with known nephrotoxic potential prior to contrast use

options.label: D
options.text: Replacing contrast-enhanced CT with gadolinium-enhanced MRI

questions.correct_answer: D. Replacing contrast-enhanced CT with gadolinium-enhanced MRI
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Replacing contrast-enhanced CT with gadolinium-enhanced MRI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gadolinium-enhanced MRI is not considered a safe alternative to iodinated contrast imaging in patients with diabetic nephropathy, due to the risk of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis. Preventive strategies for CIN include hydration, use of iso-osmolar contrast, and stopping nephrotoxic agents.
  • ➤ Gadolinium-enhanced MRI is not considered a safe alternative to iodinated contrast imaging in patients with diabetic nephropathy, due to the risk of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis.
  • ➤ Preventive strategies for CIN include hydration, use of iso-osmolar contrast, and stopping nephrotoxic agents.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF) are true? Acute rheumatic fever occurs due to direct bacterial invasion of the cardiac tissue by group A β-hemolytic streptococci. Diagnosis of ARF requires evidence of recent streptococcal infection along with major or minor Jones criteria. Aschoff bodies seen in myocarditis consist of fibrinoid necrosis, chronic inflammation, and characteristic Anitschkow cells. Mitral valve is the most commonly affected valve in rheumatic carditis, typically resulting in regurgitation during the acute phase. Lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are included among the major Jones criteria.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2, 3, and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute Rheumatic Fever is a post-streptococcal autoimmune disease diagnosed by Jones criteria. It involves molecular mimicry (not direct bacterial invasion), classically affects the mitral valve, and shows Aschoff bodies in myocarditis—the main cause of death in the acute phase.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman in her second month of pregnancy presents with fever, chills, and fatigue. Peripheral blood smear confirms Plasmodium vivax infection. questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with fatigue, dry cough, and shortness of breath. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. questions.text: A hospital aims to increase bed availability and patient turnover by reducing the average length of hospital stays by 20%. If the hospital's baseline data shows an average stay of 5 days with 6000 admissions annually and a 100% occupancy rate, how many beds are required to maintain a 95% occupancy rate after implementing this policy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 69 beds

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Efficient Resource Management in Healthcare : Reducing the average length of hospital stays can significantly improve bed turnover rates and resource utilization. This strategy allows hospitals to manage more patients effectively without needing to expand their physical capacity. Implementing a 20% reduction in the average stay not only maximizes the use of existing bed space but also enhances the hospital's ability to maintain high-quality care under nearly full occupancy conditions.
  • ➤ Efficient Resource Management in Healthcare : Reducing the average length of hospital stays can significantly improve bed turnover rates and resource utilization.

questions.text: Match List I (Age Group) with List II (Corpus: Cervix Ratio). List I (Age Group) Before puberty Reproductive age Menopause At puberty List II (Corpus: Cervix Ratio) 1:1 2:1 3:1 1:2 1:3

questions.text: Match the clinical pattern of alopecia in Column A with their corresponding description in Column B. questions.text: A 37-year-old male diagnosed with squint presents to the ophthalmology department for a routine check-up. On examination, the medial rectus muscle is found to be affected, as seen in the given CT scan. At which level does the nerve supplying the marked structure arise?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Red nucleus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The medial rectus muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (CN III), which arises at the level of the superior colliculus, near the red nucleus. Damage to the oculomotor nerve can cause medial rectus palsy, leading to an inability to adduct the eye (exotropia). The red nucleus is a crucial midbrain structure related to CN III, while subthalamic, pyramidal, and olivary structures have no direct role in extraocular muscle control.
  • ➤ The medial rectus muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (CN III), which arises at the level of the superior colliculus, near the red nucleus.
  • ➤ Damage to the oculomotor nerve can cause medial rectus palsy, leading to an inability to adduct the eye (exotropia).
  • ➤ The red nucleus is a crucial midbrain structure related to CN III, while subthalamic, pyramidal, and olivary structures have no direct role in extraocular muscle control.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with moderate major depressive disorder has been on escitalopram for the past 3 months. While his mood symptoms have significantly improved, he now complains of difficulty achieving orgasm and reduced libido. He is concerned about these sexual side effects and requests a change in medication. Which of the following antidepressants is most appropriate to switch to in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Agomelatine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Agomelatine is a melatonin receptor agonist (MT1, MT2) and 5-HT₂C antagonist, used in depression. It has minimal sexual side effects due to a non-serotonergic mechanism, making it ideal for patients with SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction. Also improves sleep-wake rhythm disturbances in depression, but requires LFT monitoring due to rare hepatotoxicity.
  • ➤ Agomelatine is a melatonin receptor agonist (MT1, MT2) and 5-HT₂C antagonist, used in depression.
  • ➤ It has minimal sexual side effects due to a non-serotonergic mechanism, making it ideal for patients with SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and palpitations. Examination reveals a loud S1, opening snap, and a mid-diastolic murmur at the apex. questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding emergency contraception are true? Statements: Levonorgestrel (Plan B single step) is effective up to 120 hours after unprotected intercourse. Ulipristal is a selective progesterone receptor modulator used within 5 days for emergency contraception. The Yuzpe method consists of Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg taken in a single dose. Copper IUDs can be inserted within 7 days after unprotected intercourse for emergency contraception.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Levonorgestrel (Plan B) is effective for up to 72h hours post-intercourse. Ulipristal is a selective progesterone receptor modulator effective within 5 days. The Yuzpe method uses Ethinyl estradiol + Levonorgestrel, NOT just Levonorgestrel alone. Copper IUDs provide long-term contraception and emergency contraception within 5 days. Centchroman (Chhaya) is NOT a one-time emergency contraceptive but a regular contraceptive pill.
  • ➤ Levonorgestrel (Plan B) is effective for up to 72h hours post-intercourse.
  • ➤ Ulipristal is a selective progesterone receptor modulator effective within 5 days.
  • ➤ The Yuzpe method uses Ethinyl estradiol + Levonorgestrel, NOT just Levonorgestrel alone.
  • ➤ Copper IUDs provide long-term contraception and emergency contraception within 5 days.
  • ➤ Centchroman (Chhaya) is NOT a one-time emergency contraceptive but a regular contraceptive pill.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that began approximately 3 hours ago. Visual acuity is reduced to light perception only in the affected eye. A relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is noted on examination. The anterior segment of both eyes appears normal, but fundoscopic examination of the right eye reveals a pale retina with a red lesion at the macula. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 3-month history of progressive, localized pain in his lumbar spine. questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. A CT scan reveals retroperitoneal hematomas. The trauma team discusses the appropriate management based on the zones of retroperitoneal trauma and the patient’s hemodynamic status. Which of the following statements regarding retroperitoneal trauma are true? Zone 1- injuries often involve major vascular structures and should be surgically explored. Zone 2- hematomas, if non-expanding, should be managed conservatively. Zone 3- injuries are primarily managed with external fixation or angiographic embolization. Mattox maneuver involves mobilization of the ascending colon to expose the inferior vena cava (IVC). All Zone 2 injuries require immediate surgical exploration.

Zone 2 (Flank/Kidney area): Conservative treatment unless the hematoma is expanding . Zone 3 (Pelvis): Managed non-surgically with external fixation or embolization due to high risks of iatrogenic injury. Mattox maneuver exposes the aorta, not the IVC. Surgical exploration is only needed when indicated by ongoing hemorrhage or instability.

Zone 2 (Flank/Kidney area): Conservative treatment unless the hematoma is expanding . questions.text: The given image represents serum immunoglobulin levels (% of adult values) in a pediatric patient. What does ‘A’ represent in the given image?

options.text: Genetic testing for globin gene mutations

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Serum ferritin studies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with microcytic hypochromic anemia, elevated RDW, and low RBC count, serum ferritin is the most appropriate confirmatory test to diagnose iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue and frequent infections. He does not have a sibling. Examination reveals pallor and petechiae but no lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly. CBC shows pancytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy is done, and it is shown below. What is the most definitive treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Triple therapy with Eltrombopag

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In aplastic anemia without a matched sibling donor, immunosuppressive triple therapy with Eltrombopag is the definitive treatment.

questions.text: Assertion-Reason Assertion: The ureter may get injured during Total Abdominal Hysterectomy (TAH) if precaution is not taken while clamping the uterine artery. Reason: The ureter travels alongside the uterine artery and runs under the uterine artery within the broad ligament. This proximity makes it vulnerable to accidental injury during dissection and ligation of the uterine artery, especially if the ureter is not carefully identified and separated.

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and Reason is the correct explanation of Assertion.

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are correct, but Reason is not the correct explanation of Assertion.

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is correct, but Reason is incorrect.

options.label: D
options.text: Reason is correct, but Assertion is incorrect.

questions.correct_answer: A. Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and Reason is the correct explanation of Assertion.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and Reason is the correct explanation of Assertion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The uterine artery runs transversely, while the ureter runs in an AP direction, leading to their crossover in the parametrium. This anatomical relationship increases the risk of ureteric injury during uterine artery ligation in hysterectomy. Surgeons must take special care during clamping to avoid complications.
  • ➤ The uterine artery runs transversely, while the ureter runs in an AP direction, leading to their crossover in the parametrium.
  • ➤ This anatomical relationship increases the risk of ureteric injury during uterine artery ligation in hysterectomy.
  • ➤ Surgeons must take special care during clamping to avoid complications.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Congenital Melanocytic Nevus (CMN) are true? CMN is typically a well-circumscribed, pigmented lesion that is often covered with hair. Large or giant CMN (>20 cm) have a lower risk of malignant melanoma compared to small CMN. Intraparenchymal melanosis is the most common neurological complication associated with CMN. Management of small CMN includes observation, while large CMN may need surgical excision. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common complication seen in CMN.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 3, and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN) presents as a pigmented, often hairy lesion present from birth. Larger lesions carry a higher risk of malignant melanoma and neurological complications such as intraparenchymal melanosis. Management varies with size and risk of malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with COPD exacerbation is admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress, altered mental status, and a PaCO₂ of 75 mmHg on arterial blood gas analysis. He is placed on mechanical ventilation. After intubation, his peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) rises significantly, and the expiratory flow does not return to baseline before the next breath on the ventilator waveform. His blood pressure drops, and he develops tachycardia. What is the most likely cause of his clinical deterioration?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Auto-PEEP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In mechanically ventilated COPD patients , ensure adequate expiratory time (low respiratory rate, high inspiratory flow rates) to prevent auto-PEEP and hemodynamic instability.
  • ➤ mechanically ventilated COPD patients
  • ➤ adequate expiratory time (low respiratory rate, high inspiratory flow rates)
  • ➤ prevent auto-PEEP

questions.text: A 52-year-old male is admitted with a skin and soft tissue infection following a surgical wound complication. Empiric antibiotic therapy with a β-lactam agent is started, but the infection fails to respond. Culture of the wound exudate reveals Staphylococcus aureus, resistant to methicillin. Molecular analysis of the bacterial isolate identifies a genetic alteration that confers resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics. This resistance mechanism is primarily due to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) PBP alteration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus is caused by acquisition of the mecA gene, which encodes an altered penicillin-binding protein (PBP2a) that has low affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics, allowing continued cell wall synthesis despite antibiotic presence.

questions.text: In the context of emerging infectious diseases, which of the following should be closely studied for its potential interspecies transmission and subsequent zoonotic outbreaks?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nipah Virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nipah virus is a high-priority emerging zoonotic pathogen due to its ability to transmit between species , especially from animals (e.g., fruit bats and pigs) to humans, leading to severe and often fatal respiratory and neurological illness . Its epidemic potential and high case fatality rate make it a critical target for surveillance, early detection, and intersectoral One Health approaches in public health.
  • ➤ Nipah virus
  • ➤ transmit between species
  • ➤ severe and often fatal respiratory and neurological illness
  • ➤ epidemic potential
  • ➤ high case fatality rate
  • ➤ surveillance, early detection, and intersectoral One Health approaches

questions.text: Match the neurological disorders in Column A with their characteristic EEG findings in Column B. Column A (Neurological Disorder) West syndrome Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) Absence seizures Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy Lennox-Gastaut syndrome Column B (EEG Feature) 4-5 Hz spike Periodic biphasic or triphasic sharp-wave complexes 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern) Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background) 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves with polyspike bursts in sleep
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-D, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A, 5-E

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ EEG findings are essential for diagnosing epilepsy syndromes and neurodegenerative diseases. West syndrome shows hypsarrhythmia, while absence seizures are characterized by 3 Hz spike-wave patterns. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease presents with periodic sharp waves, differentiating it from other encephalopathies. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome have distinct EEG patterns critical for diagnosis and treatment planning.
  • ➤ EEG findings are essential for diagnosing epilepsy syndromes and neurodegenerative diseases.
  • ➤ West syndrome shows hypsarrhythmia, while absence seizures are characterized by 3 Hz spike-wave patterns.
  • ➤ Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease presents with periodic sharp waves, differentiating it from other encephalopathies.
  • ➤ Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome have distinct EEG patterns critical for diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with complaints of excessive tearing from her right eye. She denies pain, discharge, or recent trauma. An ophthalmic evaluation is performed, and both Jones Test I and Jones Test II are negative. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Inadequate eyelid closure due to orbicularis weakness

options.label: B
options.text: Partial obstruction of distal nasolacrimal duct

options.label: D
options.text: Primary hypersecretion due to reflex tearing

questions.correct_answer: A. Inadequate eyelid closure due to orbicularis weakness
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inadequate eyelid closure due to orbicularis weakness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In elderly patients with epiphora and both Jones Tests negative, lacrimal pump failure due to orbicularis oculi weakness must be considered as a functional cause of impaired tear drainage, even in the absence of anatomical obstruction.

questions.text: Match the Aortic Arch in Column A with their corresponding developmental derivatives in Column B: Column A (Aortic Arch) 1st Aortic Arch 2nd Aortic Arch 3rd Aortic Arch 4th Aortic Arch 5th Aortic Arch 6th Aortic Arch Column B (Developmental Derivative) Left: Arch of aorta between left common carotid and left subclavian; Right: Right subclavian artery Maxillary artery Hyoid artery Common carotid artery, Proximal part of internal carotid and external carotid artery Proximal part: Pulmonary artery; Distal part: Ductus arteriosus on left, disappears on right Disappear completely
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-B, 2-C, 3-D, 4-A, 5-F, 6-E

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought in for evaluation after the parents noticed an apparent eye misalignment in recent photographs. The child has had normal development, with no concerns during pregnancy or delivery. On physical examination, the corneal light reflex is symmetric, and no true misalignment is observed. However, the child has a broad nasal bridge and prominent epicanthal folds. All other ophthalmologic findings are within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pseudostrabismus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pseudostrabismus is a benign condition in young children caused by facial features like epicanthal folds or a flat nasal bridge, creating a false impression of eye deviation. Diagnosis is confirmed by a symmetric corneal light reflex and absence of true ocular misalignment.
  • ➤ Pseudostrabismus is a benign condition in young children caused by facial features like epicanthal folds or a flat nasal bridge, creating a false impression of eye deviation.
  • ➤ Diagnosis is confirmed by a symmetric corneal light reflex and absence of true ocular misalignment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding different patterns of vitiligo are true? Segmental vitiligo commonly involves the trigeminal nerve distribution and is associated with autoimmune diseases. Vitiligo vulgaris is the most common type and shows widespread distribution with possible family history. Acrofacial vitiligo involves the lips, penis, and nipple, and shows excellent response to treatment due to rich hair density. Segmental vitiligo often shows leukotrichia and has a relatively stable clinical course. Vitiligo universalis is typically localized to the periorbital and perioral areas.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 and 4 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitiligo presents in various patterns, with vitiligo vulgaris being the most common. Segmental vitiligo occurs in children, is not autoimmune-associated, and shows leukotrichia with poor treatment response.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with progressive lower limb weakness and numbness following a diarrheal illness two weeks ago. Examination shows hypotonia, areflexia, and bilateral flaccid paralysis in the legs. Sensation is preserved. Past medical records indicate that she has been suffering from selective IgA deficiency. What is the best initial treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Plasma Exchange

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Plasma exchange is the treatment of choice for GBS in patients with IgA deficiency, where IVIG is contraindicated.
  • ➤ Plasma exchange
  • ➤ choice for GBS
  • ➤ with IgA
  • ➤ IVIG
  • ➤ contraindicated.

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory investigations would most accurately confirm the diagnosis of rotavirus diarrhea?

options.label: D
options.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.correct_answer: D. Antigen detection in the stool sample
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Antigen detection in the stool sample

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnosis of rotavirus diarrhea is best confirmed by detecting rotavirus antigen in stool samples using enzyme immunoassay or latex agglutination techniques.

questions.text: A microbiology lab is reviewing culture and staining characteristics to confirm a suspected case of pertussis. Which of the following statements regarding Bordetella pertussis is incorrect? The most appropriate specimen for isolation is a nasopharyngeal aspirate. Regan-Lowe medium and Bordet-Gengou agar are used for culturing the organism. The colonies typically exhibit a metallic sheen with black center on eosin methylene blue agar. On culture, colonies may resemble mercury drops or bisected pearls. Gram-stained smears may show coccobacilli in a thumbprint arrangement.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Only 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bordetella pertussis does not grow on eosin methylene blue (EMB) agar; it requires special media such as Bordet-Gengou or Regan-Lowe. Colonies show mercury drop appearance, and the organism appears as coccobacilli in a thumbprint pattern on smear.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding seminoma are true? 1. Histology reveals large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei, resembling spermatogonia 2. Seminoma is the most common testicular tumor and resembles ovarian dysgerminoma 3. It commonly presents with hemorrhage and necrosis within the testicular mass 4. It is radiosensitive and associated with an excellent prognosis 5. β-hCG is always elevated and required for diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Seminoma is the most common testicular tumor, composed of large clear cells with central nuclei. It forms a homogeneous mass without hemorrhage or necrosis, resembles ovarian dysgerminoma, is radiosensitive, and has an excellent prognosis. β-hCG may be elevated in rare cases.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis secondary to hepatitis B is being evaluated for liver transplantation due to hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Imaging reveals three tumors measuring 2.5 cm, 3.0 cm, and 3.2 cm, with no evidence of extrahepatic spread or vascular invasion. According to the Milan Criteria, is this patient eligible for liver transplantation?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because he has no macrovascular invasion or extrahepatic disease.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because he exceeds the tumor size criteria.

options.label: C
options.text: No, as the Milan criteria are not applicable if more than 2 tumours are present on imaging.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because the Milan criteria only allow a single tumor ≤5 cm.

questions.correct_answer: B. No, because he exceeds the tumor size criteria.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) No, because he exceeds the tumor size criteria.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Milan Criteria is the gold standard for selecting HCC patients for liver transplantation . It ensures optimal survival outcomes while minimizing recurrence risk. Patients exceeding Milan Criteria may be considered under expanded criteria (e.g., UCSF criteria) or down-staged before listing .
  • ➤ Milan Criteria is the gold standard for selecting HCC patients for liver transplantation .
  • ➤ Milan Criteria
  • ➤ gold standard
  • ➤ HCC patients for liver transplantation
  • ➤ It ensures optimal survival outcomes while minimizing recurrence risk.
  • ➤ optimal survival outcomes
  • ➤ Patients exceeding Milan Criteria may be considered under expanded criteria (e.g., UCSF criteria) or down-staged before listing .
  • ➤ may be considered under expanded criteria
  • ➤ down-staged before listing

questions.text: The production of mRNA in eukaryotic cells requires a large number of steps, and drugs targeted to any of these steps could block mRNA production. Which one of the following accurately describes a part of the process of producing mRNA from a eukaryotic gene?

options.label: A
options.text: The sense strand of DNA is the strand used by RNA polymerase during transcription.

options.label: B
options.text: The antisense DNA strand is identical to the RNA transcript except that the DNA strand contains thymine and the RNA strand contains uracil.

options.label: C
options.text: The first RNA form produced contains both intron and exon sequences.

options.label: D
options.text: Mature mRNA contains a cap at the 5′-end, a poly(A) tail at the 3′ end, introns, and exons.

questions.correct_answer: C. The first RNA form produced contains both intron and exon sequences.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The first RNA form produced contains both intron and exon sequences.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial RNA transcript (hnRNA) in eukaryotic cells contains both introns and exons and must undergo splicing and other modifications before becoming mature mRNA.

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker presents with progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and unintentional weight loss over 3 months. Examination reveals digital clubbing and decreased breath sounds on the right. Chest X-ray shows a right hilar mass. CT-guided biopsy confirms small cell lung carcinoma. Lab results reveal serum sodium of 122 mmol/L and urine sodium of 60 mmol/L with high urine osmolality. What is the most appropriate initial step in managing hyponatremia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fluid restriction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fluid restriction is the first-line treatment for SIADH-induced hyponatremia in the setting of small cell lung carcinoma.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman recently completed a 10-day course of clindamycin for cellulitis. Two weeks later, she presents with watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and low-grade fever. Stool testing is positive for Clostridioides difficile toxin B gene. She is diagnosed with non-severe initial CDI and has no history of prior infections. Which of the following medications should be prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fidaxomicin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fidaxomicin is a first-line oral antibiotic for Clostridioides difficile infection. It acts by inhibiting the sigma subunit of RNA polymerase and is associated with lower recurrence rates compared to vancomycin.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with 3-day history of gross hematuria. He reports no fever, rash, or history of recent infections. Vital signs are stable, but his laboratory tests show a blood urea nitrogen of 39 mg/dL and creatinine of 4.1 mg/dL. A renal biopsy is performed, and immunofluorescence microscopy using anti-IgG shows a linear pattern along the glomerular basement membrane (shown in the image below). Which of the following serologic findings is most likely to be detected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anti–glomerular basement membrane antibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A linear pattern of IgG staining along the glomerular basement membrane on immunofluorescence is diagnostic for anti–GBM disease. This autoimmune condition is confirmed by detecting anti–glomerular basement membrane antibodies in the serum.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. Drug susceptibility testing reveals resistance to isoniazid, rifampicin, and one of the levofloxacin. He has no prior history of tuberculosis treatment. Which of the following best describes this resistance pattern?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pre-extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (Pre-XDR-TB)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pre-extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (Pre-XDR-TB) is defined as TB resistant to isoniazid, rifampicin, and any fluoroquinolone (e.g., levofloxacin), and must be recognized for appropriate treatment planning.

questions.text: Match the conditions in Column A with their most commonly associated pathogens in Column B. Column A (Conditions) Acute epiglottitis Furunculosis Otomycosis Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis Column B (Pathogens) Aspergillus niger Staphylococcus aureus Aspergillus fumigatus Haemophilus influenzae
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A-4, B-2, C-1, D-3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Haemophilus influenzae is the most common cause of acute epiglottitis . Staphylococcus aureus frequently causes furunculosis (boil formation). Aspergillus niger is a major cause of otomycosis (fungal ear infection). Aspergillus fumigatus is commonly associated with allergic fungal rhinosinusitis .
  • ➤ Haemophilus influenzae is the most common cause of acute epiglottitis .
  • ➤ Haemophilus influenzae
  • ➤ acute epiglottitis
  • ➤ Staphylococcus aureus frequently causes furunculosis (boil formation).
  • ➤ Staphylococcus aureus
  • ➤ furunculosis
  • ➤ Aspergillus niger is a major cause of otomycosis (fungal ear infection).
  • ➤ Aspergillus niger
  • ➤ otomycosis
  • ➤ Aspergillus fumigatus is commonly associated with allergic fungal rhinosinusitis .
  • ➤ Aspergillus fumigatus
  • ➤ allergic fungal rhinosinusitis

questions.text: In a systematic review assessing the effectiveness of a novel antidepressant, researchers utilize a funnel plot to evaluate the integrity of the data compiled from various studies. Upon analysis, they observe notable asymmetry in the funnel plot. Considering this finding, a clinical researcher is concerned about the biases affecting the results. What does the observed asymmetry in the funnel plot most likely indicate about the studies included in the meta-analysis?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of randomization in individual studies.

options.label: B
options.text: An increased likelihood of publication bias.

options.label: C
options.text: Overestimation of the intervention’s effect size.

questions.correct_answer: B. An increased likelihood of publication bias.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) An increased likelihood of publication bias.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify funnel plot asymmetry as a sign of publication bias in meta-analyses, indicating a potential exclusion of smaller or negative studies that skews results toward positive outcomes. Recognize the importance of strategies to mitigate this bias for accurate conclusions.
  • ➤ Identify funnel plot asymmetry as a sign of publication bias in meta-analyses, indicating a potential exclusion of smaller or negative studies that skews results toward positive outcomes.
  • ➤ Recognize the importance of strategies to mitigate this bias for accurate conclusions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) and intermenstrual spotting for the past 6 months. She has no history of pelvic inflammatory disease or recent infections. A transvaginal ultrasound is inconclusive, so the physician performs a hysterosalpingography (HSG) to evaluate the uterine cavity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Endometrial Polyp

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endometrial polyps are common causes of abnormal uterine bleeding and appear as smooth, intracavitary filling defects on HSG. Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosis and treatment. Differentiate from submucosal fibroids (irregular filling defects) and Asherman syndrome (intrauterine adhesions).
  • ➤ Endometrial polyps are common causes of abnormal uterine bleeding and appear as smooth, intracavitary filling defects on HSG.
  • ➤ Endometrial polyps
  • ➤ common causes of abnormal uterine bleeding
  • ➤ smooth, intracavitary filling defects on HSG.
  • ➤ Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosis and treatment.
  • ➤ Differentiate from submucosal fibroids (irregular filling defects) and Asherman syndrome (intrauterine adhesions).

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding the contributions of these historical figures to medicine? Andreas Vesalius authored "De Humani Corporis Fabrica" and advanced anatomical science with detailed human dissections. Samuel Hahnemann founded the practice of Naturopathy. Avicenna wrote "The Canon of Medicine," which was used as a standard medical text in the Islamic world and Europe. Charaka is known as the father of Western medicine.

Ans. C) 1 and 3

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with known HIV presents with 3 weeks of cough, fever, and weight loss. He has discontinued his ART 2 years ago. Chest X-ray shows bilateral upper lobe cavitary lesions and sputum is positive for acid-fast bacilli. His CD4 count is 180 cells/mm³. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Start antitubercular therapy first, then ART after 2 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: Start both ART and ATT on day one

questions.correct_answer: B. Start antitubercular therapy first, then ART after 2 weeks
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Start antitubercular therapy first, then ART after 2 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In HIV-TB co-infection with CD4 >100, ART should be delayed by 2 weeks after starting ATT to reduce the risk of IRIS.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with jaundice, pedal edema, and splenomegaly is admitted for worsening abdominal distension. Labs show: • Sodium (Na⁺): 140 mEq/L • Chloride (Cl⁻): 115 mEq/L • Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻): 26 mEq/L Which of the following best explains the anion gap?

options.label: B
options.text: Hypoalbuminemia leading to a reduction in the anion gap

options.label: C
options.text: Unmeasured cation excess due to multiple myeloma

questions.correct_answer: B. Hypoalbuminemia leading to a reduction in the anion gap
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypoalbuminemia leading to a reduction in the anion gap

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypoalbuminemia is the most common cause of a low anion gap . Since albumin is a major unmeasured anion, its reduction leads to a decrease in AG. Always adjust the AG in hypoalbuminemic patients to avoid missing conditions that would otherwise cause a high AG.
  • ➤ Hypoalbuminemia
  • ➤ most common cause of a low anion gap

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and audible bilateral expiratory wheezing. He has a history of intermittent asthma but is not currently on any controller medication. On auscultation, diffuse wheezes are noted bilaterally, and his oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aerosolized ipratropium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aerosolized short-acting β2-agonists are the first-line treatment for acute bronchospasm due to asthma, providing rapid bronchodilation and symptom relief.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with fatigue, weight loss, and a history of poor appetite over several weeks. Urinalysis reveals positive ketones but no glucose in the urine. Blood glucose levels are within the normal range. The findings suggest a condition in which the body increases fat breakdown in the absence of hyperglycemia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Prolonged starvation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prolonged starvation leads to ketonuria in the absence of glycosuria due to increased fat metabolism and normal blood glucose levels.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Wobble Hypothesis are correct? The phenomenon explains how one tRNA can recognize multiple codons. The 3rd nucleotide of the anticodon on tRNA exhibits reduced specificity. The 3rd nucleotide of the codon on mRNA is responsible for wobble pairing. Wobble base pairing contributes to redundancy in the genetic code. The 1st base of the codon on mRNA shows most variability in wobble base pairing.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 3, and 4 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Wobble Hypothesis explains how one tRNA can pair with multiple codons through flexible base pairing at the 3rd position of the mRNA codon, contributing to genetic code redundancy without changing the amino acid.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of previous laparotomy presents with a midline abdominal bulge that increases with straining. CT scan reveals a ventral hernia with a defect of 6 cm in width without loss of domain. According to the European Hernia Society (EHS) classification, which category does this hernia belong to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) W2 Midline Hernia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ EHS Classification helps standardize ventral hernia categorization based on location (Midline vs. Lateral) and size . Midline hernias are labelled W1, W2, W3 based on defect width. Lateral hernias are labelled L1, L2, L3 with similar width criteria. Accurate classification is crucial for surgical planning and determining repair techniques .
  • ➤ EHS Classification helps standardize ventral hernia categorization based on location (Midline vs. Lateral) and size .
  • ➤ EHS Classification
  • ➤ ventral hernia categorization
  • ➤ location (Midline vs. Lateral) and size
  • ➤ Midline hernias are labelled W1, W2, W3 based on defect width.
  • ➤ Midline hernias
  • ➤ W1, W2, W3
  • ➤ Lateral hernias are labelled L1, L2, L3 with similar width criteria.
  • ➤ Lateral hernias
  • ➤ L1, L2, L3
  • ➤ Accurate classification is crucial for surgical planning and determining repair techniques .
  • ➤ Accurate classification
  • ➤ surgical planning
  • ➤ repair techniques

questions.text: Match the Following: Drugs and Their Teratogenic Effects Match List I (Drugs) with List II (Teratogenic Effects). List I (Drugs) Methotrexate SSRI Warfarin Sodium Valproate List II (Teratogenic Effects) Neural tube defects, cleft lip, cardiovascular defects Cranial anomalies, limb defects, neural tube defects Congenital cardiac anomalies Nasal hypoplasia, midface hypoplasia, stippled epiphyses, skeletal defects
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methotrexate → Cranial and limb defects, neural tube defects SSRI (Paroxetine) → Congenital cardiac anomalies Warfarin → Fetal warfarin syndrome (nasal hypoplasia, skeletal defects, stippled epiphyses) Sodium Valproate → Neural tube defects, cleft lip, cardiovascular malformations.
  • ➤ Methotrexate → Cranial and limb defects, neural tube defects
  • ➤ SSRI (Paroxetine) → Congenital cardiac anomalies
  • ➤ Warfarin → Fetal warfarin syndrome (nasal hypoplasia, skeletal defects, stippled epiphyses)
  • ➤ Sodium Valproate → Neural tube defects, cleft lip, cardiovascular malformations.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a large swelling extending downward and medially below the left costal margin. On percussion, a continuous band of dullness extends upward from the left of the umbilicus to the left axillary region. On palpation, a notch is felt along the anterior border of the swelling. A diagnosis of splenomegaly is made. Which of the following statements pertaining to this case is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The spleen is situated in the upper left quadrant of the abdomen beneath the diaphragm.

options.label: B
options.text: The long axis of the spleen lies along the 10th rib.

options.label: C
options.text: A pathologically enlarged spleen extends downward and forward, toward the left iliac fossa.

options.label: D
options.text: The spleen has a notched anterior border caused by incomplete fusion of its parts during development.

questions.correct_answer: C. A pathologically enlarged spleen extends downward and forward, toward the left iliac fossa.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A pathologically enlarged spleen extends downward and forward, toward the left iliac fossa.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Splenomegaly does not extend downward into the left iliac fossa due to the left colic flexure and phrenicocolic ligament. The spleen normally lies in the upper left quadrant, with its long axis parallel to the 10th rib. A notched anterior border is a characteristic anatomical feature of the spleen. On clinical examination, splenomegaly is suspected when a notch is palpable, and percussion reveals a dull note in Traube’s space.
  • ➤ Splenomegaly does not extend downward into the left iliac fossa due to the left colic flexure and phrenicocolic ligament.
  • ➤ The spleen normally lies in the upper left quadrant, with its long axis parallel to the 10th rib.
  • ➤ A notched anterior border is a characteristic anatomical feature of the spleen.
  • ➤ On clinical examination, splenomegaly is suspected when a notch is palpable, and percussion reveals a dull note in Traube’s space.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with terminal ALS (amyotrophic lateral sclerosis) is suffering from severe muscle weakness and difficulty swallowing. He requests that his doctor prescribe a lethal dose of barbiturates so that he can end his life at his chosen time. The physician complies, and the patient self-administers the drug and dies peacefully at home. Which of the following best describes this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Physician-assisted suicide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Physician-assisted suicide involves a competent patient self-administering a lethal medication provided by a physician, distinguishing it from euthanasia where the physician performs the final act.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus returns for follow-up. Despite lifestyle changes and metformin therapy, her HbA1c remains at 8.3%. Her BMI is 35 kg/m², and she expresses interest in losing weight. The physician adds an oral medication that acts through GLP-1 pathway, slows gastric emptying, promotes satiety, and enhances glucose-dependent insulin secretion. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sitagliptin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus inadequately controlled with metformin and lifestyle modifications, DPP-4 inhibitors (e.g., sitagliptin) offer an oral, weight-neutral option with low hypoglycemia risk . These drugs act by prolonging endogenous GLP-1 activity .
  • ➤ DPP-4 inhibitors
  • ➤ oral, weight-neutral
  • ➤ low hypoglycemia risk
  • ➤ prolonging endogenous GLP-1 activity

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1→C, 2→B, 3→D, 4→A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following statements are not predictors of a difficult airway? Mallampati score III and IV Thyromental distance less than 6 cm Sterno-mental distance >12.5 cm with head in maximum extension Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3 only - Sterno-mental distance >12.5 cm with head in maximum extension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ A sterno-mental distance >12.5 cm does NOT predict a difficult airway , whereas a distance <12.5 cm is a strong indicator of intubation difficulty . Proper preoperative airway assessment using multiple predictors ( Mallampati score, thyromental distance, neck mobility ) is essential to anticipate airway challenges .
  • ➤ A sterno-mental distance >12.5 cm does NOT predict a difficult airway , whereas a distance <12.5 cm is a strong indicator of intubation difficulty .
  • ➤ A sterno-mental distance >12.5 cm does NOT predict a difficult airway
  • ➤ distance <12.5 cm is a strong indicator of intubation difficulty
  • ➤ Proper preoperative airway assessment using multiple predictors ( Mallampati score, thyromental distance, neck mobility ) is essential to anticipate airway challenges .
  • ➤ preoperative airway assessment
  • ➤ Mallampati score, thyromental distance, neck mobility
  • ➤ anticipate airway challenges

questions.text: A patient in septic shock is being managed in the intensive care unit and is started on intravenous norepinephrine infusion. Which of the following parameters is the most appropriate to monitor the therapeutic response?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increased mean arterial pressure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients receiving norepinephrine for septic shock, an increase in mean arterial pressure is the best clinical indicator of a favorable response to therapy.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is admitted with fever, diarrhea, and symptoms of meningoencephalitis. Blood cultures reveal a gram-positive bacillus. MRI shows signs of CNS involvement. The organism responsible is known for its ability to move between host cells by hijacking host actin filaments for intracellular and transcellular motility, avoiding extracellular exposure to immune defenses. Which of the following organisms demonstrates this actin-based transcellular movement?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Listeria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Listeria monocytogenes uses host actin filaments for intracellular and transcellular movement, aiding immune evasion and facilitating spread to the CNS and placenta.

questions.text: Match the muscle arrangement patterns in Column A with their corresponding examples in Column B. Column A (Muscle Arrangement) Circular Convergent Parallel Pennate Column B (Example) Orbicularis oris, Orbicularis oculi Pectoralis major, Trapezius Sartorius, Biceps brachii Extensor digitorum longus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Muscle fiber arrangement determines function and strength. Circular muscles act as sphincters, convergent muscles allow powerful contractions, parallel muscles enable greater movement, and pennate muscles maximize force production.
  • ➤ Muscle fiber arrangement determines function and strength.
  • ➤ Circular muscles act as sphincters, convergent muscles allow powerful contractions, parallel muscles enable greater movement, and pennate muscles maximize force production.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with a 2-week history of a widespread non-itchy rash, including lesions on the palms of his hands and soles of his feet. He also reports malaise and low-grade fever. He denies drug use or recent new medications. Examination reveals diffuse, symmetric maculopapular lesions including on the palms and soles. Serologic testing with RPR is positive. What is the most appropriate pharmacologic treatment for this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Benzathine penicillin G, single intramuscular dose

questions.correct_answer: C. Benzathine penicillin G, single intramuscular dose
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Benzathine penicillin G, single intramuscular dose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Secondary syphilis commonly presents with a non-itchy maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles. The first-line treatment is a single intramuscular dose of benzathine penicillin G.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for generating cytosolic acetyl-CoA required for extramitochondrial fatty acid synthesis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Citrate lyase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Citrate lyase generates cytosolic acetyl-CoA from citrate, providing the essential building block for fatty acid synthesis outside the mitochondria.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy has a severe asthmatic attack with wheezing. He experiences rapid breathing and becomes cyanotic. His arterial PO₂ is 60 mm Hg and his PCO₂ is 30 mm Hg. Which of the following statements about this patient is most likely to be true?

options.label: A
options.text: Forced expiratory volume/forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC) is increased

options.label: B
options.text: Ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) ratio is increased in the affected areas of his lungs

options.label: C
options.text: His arterial PCO₂ is higher than normal because of inadequate gas exchange

options.label: D
options.text: His arterial PCO₂ is lower than normal because hypoxemia is causing him to hyperventilate

questions.correct_answer: D. His arterial PCO₂ is lower than normal because hypoxemia is causing him to hyperventilate
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) His arterial PCO₂ is lower than normal because hypoxemia is causing him to hyperventilate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In an acute asthma attack, hypoxemia results from V/Q mismatch, which triggers hyperventilation. This leads to a decreased arterial PCO₂. A low or normal PCO₂ indicates that the patient is still compensating; a high PCO₂ suggests impending respiratory failure.
  • ➤ In an acute asthma attack, hypoxemia results from V/Q mismatch, which triggers hyperventilation.
  • ➤ This leads to a decreased arterial PCO₂. A low or normal PCO₂ indicates that the patient is still compensating; a high PCO₂ suggests impending respiratory failure.

questions.text: A research team is studying the antigenic structure of rabies virus to improve diagnostic accuracy and vaccine design. They identify two key antigens—one located on the viral envelope and another associated with the capsid. Which of the following statements regarding these rabies virus antigens is incorrect? Glycoprotein G is group-specific and cross-reactive with other lyssaviruses. Nucleoprotein shows cross-reactivity with rabies-related viruses and is group-specific. Nucleoprotein is involved in forming the viral capsid and binds viral RNA. Glycoprotein G acts as a peplomer or spike embedded in the viral envelope. Glycoprotein G exhibits species-specificity and plays a role in inducing protective immunity.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Only 1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In rabies virus, glycoprotein G is species-specific and induces immunity, while nucleoprotein is group-specific and cross-reactive with related viruses. Confusing these properties can lead to incorrect diagnostic interpretation.

questions.text: Occlusion of the artery supplying blood to the marked area will cause all of the following except.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Astereognosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paracentral lobule is the highest center for micturition and defecation. Supplied by the anterior cerebral artery (ACA). Lesions cause urinary incontinence, rectal incontinence, contralateral leg weakness, and perianal anesthesia. Astereognosis results from parietal lobe lesions, not ACA occlusion affecting the paracentral lobule.
  • ➤ Paracentral lobule is the highest center for micturition and defecation.
  • ➤ Supplied by the anterior cerebral artery (ACA).
  • ➤ Lesions cause urinary incontinence, rectal incontinence, contralateral leg weakness, and perianal anesthesia.
  • ➤ Astereognosis results from parietal lobe lesions, not ACA occlusion affecting the paracentral lobule.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a 3.5 cm breast lump, palpable axillary lymph nodes, and no distant metastases. A core needle biopsy confirms invasive ductal carcinoma, and an immunohistochemistry (IHC) panel reveals ER/PR positivity, HER2 negativity, and low Ki-67 (<14%). A PET-CT scan shows no distant metastases. Which of the following statements regarding breast cancer classification, staging, and treatment are true? This type of breast cancer is highly aggressive and has the worst prognosis among all molecular subtypes. Adjuvant chemotherapy will be used in the treatment for HER2-negative, node-positive breast cancer. A tumor size of 3.5 cm and involvement of ipsilateral axillary lymph nodes places this cancer at least in Stage IIB. Breast-conserving surgery (BCS) followed by radiation therapy is contraindicated in this patient. If the patient had a 7 cm tumor with supraclavicular lymph node involvement, it would be classified as Stage IIIC.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 2, 3, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Luminal A breast cancer (ER/PR+, HER2–, low Ki-67) has the best prognosis among breast cancer subtypes. Stage IIB (T2N1M0) breast cancer is managed with surgery and adjuvant therapy. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is the preferred initial treatment for node-positive, HER2-negative, or large tumors. Breast-conserving surgery (BCS) is not contraindicated unless there are absolute contraindications. Advanced disease (e.g., N3 with supraclavicular nodes) is classified as Stage IIIC.
  • ➤ Luminal A breast cancer (ER/PR+, HER2–, low Ki-67) has the best prognosis among breast cancer subtypes.
  • ➤ Stage IIB (T2N1M0) breast cancer is managed with surgery and adjuvant therapy.
  • ➤ Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is the preferred initial treatment for node-positive, HER2-negative, or large tumors.
  • ➤ Breast-conserving surgery (BCS) is not contraindicated unless there are absolute contraindications.
  • ➤ Advanced disease (e.g., N3 with supraclavicular nodes) is classified as Stage IIIC.

questions.text: Which is the most important reason for preferring Letulle’s technique of autopsy in infants, particularly when congenital anomalies are suspected?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves removal of the brain first, which allows for better preservation of the cranial contents in cases of congenital abnormalities.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to preserve relationship between organs as they are found in situ, making it easier to identify anomalies in malformations without disturbing anatomical arrangement.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows opening the chest and abdominal cavities in sequence, which helps to better identify congenital anomalies, as compared to Ghon's, Virchow's, or Rokitansky's.

options.label: D
options.text: It involves the dissection of the spinal cord first, which is particularly useful for infants with congenital malformations.

questions.correct_answer: B. It helps to preserve relationship between organs as they are found in situ, making it easier to identify anomalies in malformations without disturbing anatomical arrangement.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It helps to preserve relationship between organs as they are found in situ, making it easier to identify anomalies in malformations without disturbing anatomical arrangement.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Letulle’s technique is preferred in infant autopsies with suspected congenital anomalies because it preserves the anatomical relationships of the organs, aiding in accurate identification of malformations .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: Which of these hernia repairs is incorrectly matched?

options.label: A
options.text: Bassini repair: Suturing conjoint tendon to inguinal ligament

options.label: B
options.text: Shouldice repair: Double breasting of fascia transversalis

options.label: C
options.text: Desarda repair: Using a strip of fascia transversalis for strengthening

options.label: D
options.text: Mayo’s repair: Double-breasting in umbilical defects

questions.correct_answer: C. Desarda repair: Using a strip of fascia transversalis for strengthening
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Desarda repair: Using a strip of fascia transversalis for strengthening

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hernia repair techniques vary based on the structures used for reinforcement. Desarda repair uses the external oblique aponeurosis , not fascia transversalis, making it unique among tissue-based hernia repairs. Accurate understanding of these techniques is essential for selecting the most appropriate surgical approach.
  • ➤ Hernia repair techniques vary based on the structures used for reinforcement.
  • ➤ Desarda repair uses the external oblique aponeurosis , not fascia transversalis, making it unique among tissue-based hernia repairs.
  • ➤ external oblique aponeurosis
  • ➤ Accurate understanding of these techniques is essential for selecting the most appropriate surgical approach.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with fever, sore throat, and tender cervical lymphadenopathy. A monospot (Paul-Bunnell) test is ordered as part of his evaluation. The test returns positive. What is the principle behind the Paul-Bunnell (Monospot) test?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Heterophile antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Paul-Bunnell (Monospot) test detects heterophile antibodies produced in Epstein-Barr virus infection and is based on agglutination of animal red blood cells.

questions.text: During a psychoanalysis session, a patient begins to project intense emotions onto the therapist, stating that the therapist reminds them of their overly critical father. Which Freudian concept does this best exemplify?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Transference

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transference refers to the feelings that a patient develops toward the doctor; it is a combination of emotions the patient had toward important figures from the past and real feelings toward the clinician.

questions.text: Match the genetic syndromes in Column A with their characteristic clinical features in Column B. Column A Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome Apert syndrome Kabuki makeup syndrome Biotinidase (Multiple carboxylase) deficiency Column B Mitten hands Eversion of the lateral third of the lower eyelid Broad thumbs and great toes Alopecia, skin rash
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome : Broad thumbs and toes. Apert syndrome : Syndactyly ("Mitten hands") and craniosynostosis. Kabuki syndrome : Facial dysmorphism with lower eyelid eversion. Biotinidase deficiency : Alopecia, skin rash, and metabolic complications.
  • ➤ Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome : Broad thumbs and toes.
  • ➤ Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome
  • ➤ Apert syndrome : Syndactyly ("Mitten hands") and craniosynostosis.
  • ➤ Apert syndrome
  • ➤ Kabuki syndrome : Facial dysmorphism with lower eyelid eversion.
  • ➤ Kabuki syndrome
  • ➤ Biotinidase deficiency : Alopecia, skin rash, and metabolic complications.
  • ➤ Biotinidase deficiency

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with early morning vomiting, nausea, and unsteady gait. Neurological examination shows truncal ataxia and papilledema. MRI of the brain reveals a midline cerebellar mass with heterogeneous enhancement. Histopathologic analysis from biopsy is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Medulloblastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children. It arises in the midline cerebellum, presents with signs of increased intracranial pressure and truncal ataxia, and histologically shows small round blue cells forming Homer-Wright rosettes.

questions.text: A study aims to evaluate the effect of exercise duration on heart rate variability among adults. Given the non-linear relationship expected between these variables, which regression model is most appropriate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Simple curvilinear regression

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Simple Table: Comparison of Regression Models

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with episodic headaches, palpitations, and profuse sweating for 3 months. Her blood pressure in the clinic is 180/110 mmHg. She also reports weight loss and anxiety. Plasma metanephrines are elevated. CT scan is done, and it is shown below. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Start phenoxybenzamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In pheochromocytoma, the initial treatment must begin with alpha-adrenergic blockade using phenoxybenzamine before any surgical intervention or beta blockade.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with spontaneous bloody discharge from her right nipple. She denies any pain, skin changes, or breast mass. On examination, no palpable lump is noted. A core biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Intraductal papilloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intraductal papilloma is a benign breast lesion presenting with bloody nipple discharge in premenopausal women. It shows fibrovascular projections lined by both epithelial and myoepithelial cells and must be distinguished from papillary carcinoma, which lacks myoepithelial cells.
  • ➤ Intraductal papilloma is a benign breast lesion presenting with bloody nipple discharge in premenopausal women.
  • ➤ It shows fibrovascular projections lined by both epithelial and myoepithelial cells and must be distinguished from papillary carcinoma, which lacks myoepithelial cells.

questions.text: Arrange the following structures in the correct sequence of sound transmission from the external environment to the auditory cortex. Tympanic membrane Cochlear nerve Ossicles Basilar membrane Auditory cortex Inferior colliculus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1-3-4-2-6-5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sound transmission follows a structured pathway from the ear to the brain . Mechanical vibrations are converted into neural signals in the cochlea. The auditory cortex is responsible for final perception and interpretation of sound.
  • ➤ Sound transmission follows a structured pathway from the ear to the brain .
  • ➤ structured pathway
  • ➤ ear to the brain
  • ➤ Mechanical vibrations are converted into neural signals in the cochlea.
  • ➤ Mechanical vibrations
  • ➤ neural signals
  • ➤ The auditory cortex is responsible for final perception and interpretation of sound.
  • ➤ auditory cortex
  • ➤ perception and interpretation

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves have Special Visceral Efferent (SVE) components?
questions.correct_answer: B. V, VII, IX, X, XI
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) V, VII, IX, X, XI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Special Visceral Efferent (SVE) fibers supply muscles derived from pharyngeal arches. Cranial nerves V, VII, IX, X, and XI carry these fibers and are involved in mastication, facial expression, swallowing, and phonation.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Satinsky Forceps

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mayo Forceps are heavy-duty, serrated forceps used for grasping thick tissues .
  • ➤ Mayo Forceps are heavy-duty, serrated forceps used for grasping thick tissues .
