  • ➤ grasping thick tissues

questions.text: Select all that apply regarding the levels of evidence in Evidence-Based Medicine: Systematic reviews and meta-analyses are considered the pinnacle of evidence due to their comprehensive nature and broad analysis. Case reports, while low in the hierarchy, are pivotal in identifying new diseases or side effects. Expert opinions are valued over randomized controlled trials for establishing treatment protocols. Cohort studies provide causality insights superior to those of randomized trials.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1 and 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Evidence-Pyramid in Research [From top to bottom]
  • ➤ Evidence-Pyramid in Research [From top to bottom]
  • ➤ Meta-analysis (Highest clinical relevance: GOLD STANDARD) Systematic review Cohort study Case control study Case series Case report Ideas, Editorials, Opinions Animal research In-vitro (test-tube) research (Lowest clinical relevance)
  • ➤ Meta-analysis (Highest clinical relevance: GOLD STANDARD)
  • ➤ Systematic review
  • ➤ Cohort study
  • ➤ Case control study
  • ➤ Case series
  • ➤ Case report
  • ➤ Ideas, Editorials, Opinions
  • ➤ Animal research
  • ➤ In-vitro (test-tube) research (Lowest clinical relevance)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with progressive fatigue, amenorrhea, and pruritus vulvae. On examination, she has loss of pubic and axillary hair, vitiligo patches, hypotension, and cold intolerance. She also reports recurrent skin infections and anemia. Which of the following is not a part of her treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) GnRH agonist

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Autoimmune Polyglandular Syndrome Type II, management involves hormone replacement for the failing endocrine glands—hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency, levothyroxine for hypothyroidism, and HRT for primary ovarian failure. GnRH agonists are not effective in POI and are therefore not part of its treatment.
  • ➤ GnRH agonists are not effective in POI

questions.text: In a virology research laboratory, a technician is performing a plaque assay using a monolayer of cultured cells infected with serial dilutions of a virus. After several days, distinct clear zones (plaques) form in the cell layer. What is the primary purpose of this laboratory method?
questions.correct_answer: C. Quantitative assay of viral infectivity
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Quantitative assay of viral infectivity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A plaque assay is a quantitative method used to measure the number of infectious virus particles by counting plaques, which reflect viral-induced cell lysis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and chronic smoking presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe retrosternal chest pain radiating to the left arm. He is diaphoretic and nauseated. He was diagnosed with MI and undergoes emergency PCI. One hour later, he becomes hypotensive. His lungs are clear on auscultation and there is no jugular venous distension. ECG is done and it is shown below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Administer atropine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In inferior MI with complete heart block and narrow QRS, the likely site is the AV node, which typically responds to atropine before considering pacing.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding endometriosis are true? Endometriosis is most commonly found on the posterior fornix of the vagina Serum CA-125 levels are specific for diagnosis of endometriosis Ovarian endometriomas appear as “ground glass” cysts on ultrasound Combined oral contraceptives are contraindicated in management of endometriosis Histological confirmation is required for a definitive diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 3, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endometriosis is defined as the presence of functional endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterine cavity. Common sites include the ovaries (most frequent), pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, and peritoneum. Classic symptoms include dysmenorrhea, chronic pelvic pain, dyspareunia, and infertility. Ovarian endometriomas appear as “ground glass” cysts on transvaginal ultrasound. Serum CA-125 may be elevated but is not specific; it cannot replace histological diagnosis. First-line medical therapy includes COCs, progestins, and GnRH analogues for pain relief and suppression. Gold standard for diagnosis is laparoscopy with biopsy showing endometrial tissue. Endometriosis is a hormone-dependent, inflammatory, and estrogen-driven disease that may recur after treatment.
  • ➤ Endometriosis is defined as the presence of functional endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterine cavity.
  • ➤ Common sites include the ovaries (most frequent), pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, and peritoneum.
  • ➤ Classic symptoms include dysmenorrhea, chronic pelvic pain, dyspareunia, and infertility.
  • ➤ Ovarian endometriomas appear as “ground glass” cysts on transvaginal ultrasound.
  • ➤ Serum CA-125 may be elevated but is not specific; it cannot replace histological diagnosis.
  • ➤ First-line medical therapy includes COCs, progestins, and GnRH analogues for pain relief and suppression.
  • ➤ Gold standard for diagnosis is laparoscopy with biopsy showing endometrial tissue.
  • ➤ Endometriosis is a hormone-dependent, inflammatory, and estrogen-driven disease that may recur after treatment.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with a skin ulcer on his lower leg. Culture from the ulcer reveals beta-hemolytic Streptococci. In the days prior, several children at his school had sore throats, and cultures from them also showed beta-hemolytic Streptococci. To determine whether both infections are caused by the same or different strains, which of the following bacterial characteristics would be most appropriate to compare?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C-carbohydrate Ag

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ C-carbohydrate antigen is used to classify beta-hemolytic Streptococci into Lancefield groups and helps determine whether strains are the same or different.

questions.text: In figure 2, at which labeled point on the action potential the relative refractory period is located?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 4 & 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The relative refractory period occurs during repolarization and hyperpolarization when voltage-gated K⁺ channels remain open . A stronger stimulus than usual is required to depolarize the membrane and generate another action potential. This ensures the unidirectional propagation of nerve impulses.
  • ➤ The relative refractory period occurs during repolarization and hyperpolarization when voltage-gated K⁺ channels remain open .
  • ➤ relative refractory period
  • ➤ repolarization and hyperpolarization
  • ➤ K⁺ channels remain open
  • ➤ A stronger stimulus than usual is required to depolarize the membrane and generate another action potential.
  • ➤ This ensures the unidirectional propagation of nerve impulses.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 11 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with heavy vaginal bleeding and lower abdominal cramping for the past 48 hours. On pelvic examination, the cervix is dilated, and products of conception are visible in the cervical Os. A transvaginal ultrasound confirms an empty gestational sac in the uterine cavity. Her vital signs are stable. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Administration of misoprostol for medical management

options.label: D
options.text: Initiation of antibiotic therapy and observation

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Immediate Surgical Evacuation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inevitable abortion is diagnosed when products of conception are visible in the cervical os with an open cervix . Surgical evacuation (D&C or suction curettage) is the preferred management to prevent complications. Expectant and medical management (misoprostol) are only options when the cervix is closed , as seen in missed or incomplete abortions .
  • ➤ Inevitable abortion is diagnosed when products of conception are visible in the cervical os with an open cervix .
  • ➤ Inevitable abortion
  • ➤ products of conception are visible in the cervical os
  • ➤ an open cervix
  • ➤ Surgical evacuation (D&C or suction curettage) is the preferred management to prevent complications.
  • ➤ Surgical evacuation (D&C or suction curettage) is the preferred management
  • ➤ Expectant and medical management (misoprostol) are only options when the cervix is closed , as seen in missed or incomplete abortions .
  • ➤ Expectant and medical management (misoprostol) are only options when the cervix is closed
  • ➤ missed or incomplete abortions

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the combination therapy of Valsartan and Sacubitril (ARNI) is incorrect? Valsartan blocks angiotensin II type 1 receptors, reducing vasoconstriction and aldosterone release. Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin, leading to increased levels of natriuretic peptides. ARNI therapy is first line for all patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). The combination has been shown to reduce mortality and hospitalizations in HFrEF. ARNI therapy should not be co-administered with ACE inhibitors due to the risk of angioedema.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Only statement 3 is incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Valsartan–sacubitril (ARNI) is indicated for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. Sacubitril increases natriuretic peptides via neprilysin inhibition, while valsartan blocks angiotensin II receptors. This combination should not be used with ACE inhibitors due to angioedema risk and is not first-line for HFpEF.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a 3-year history of type 2 diabetes presents with gradually worsening swelling in both legs, increased fatigue, and frothy urine for the past 2 months. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. Investigations reveal serum creatinine of 1.6 mg/dL, 24-hour urinary protein of 4.8 grams, serum albumin of 2.4 g/dL, and LDL cholesterol of 280 mg/dL. Fundoscopy is normal. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Renal biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In diabetic patients with nephrotic-range proteinuria and no retinopathy, consider non-diabetic kidney disease and proceed with renal biopsy.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman, a known case of Alzheimer’s disease, presents with involuntary urine leakage, especially when she is unable to reach the bathroom in time. She reports frequent urgency to urinate but passes only small amounts each time. An anticholinergic medication is prescribed to improve bladder control that does not cross the blood-brain barrier, thereby minimizing central nervous system side effects. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Trospium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trospium is an anticholinergic drug used for overactive bladder that does not cross the blood-brain barrier, making it suitable for elderly patients or those with Alzheimer’s disease to avoid central nervous system side effects.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child presents with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips, and hepatosplenomegaly. He also has copious nasal discharge and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. On examination, the child has joint stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hurler Disease (Mucopolysaccharidosis Type I)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hurler syndrome (MPS I) presents with coarse facies, macroglossia, hepatosplenomegaly, skeletal dysplasia, and recurrent respiratory infections. Caused by L-iduronidase deficiency, leading to glycosaminoglycan (GAG) accumulation. Diagnosis confirmed by enzyme assay and genetic testing. Bone marrow transplantation and enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) are the mainstay treatments.
  • ➤ Hurler syndrome (MPS I) presents with coarse facies, macroglossia, hepatosplenomegaly, skeletal dysplasia, and recurrent respiratory infections.
  • ➤ Caused by L-iduronidase deficiency, leading to glycosaminoglycan (GAG) accumulation.
  • ➤ Diagnosis confirmed by enzyme assay and genetic testing.
  • ➤ Bone marrow transplantation and enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) are the mainstay treatments.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of moderate persistent asthma presents to the emergency department with worsening dyspnea and chest tightness over the past 12 hours. She has already taken multiple doses of inhaled salbutamol without relief. On examination, she is speaking in short phrases, has marked use of accessory muscles, and a silent chest on auscultation. Arterial blood gas reveals pH 7.21, PaCO₂ 58 mmHg, and PaO₂ 64 mmHg. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.correct_answer: C. Immediate intubation and mechanical ventilation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Immediate intubation and mechanical ventilation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In a patient with severe asthma and evidence of ventilatory failure, immediate endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation are lifesaving and should not be delayed.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause a drug interaction by inhibiting cytochrome P450 enzymes, leading to increased plasma concentrations of co-administered drugs?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ketoconazole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ketoconazole is a strong inhibitor of cytochrome P450 enzymes, particularly CYP3A4, and can increase the plasma concentration of co-administered drugs by reducing their metabolism.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man who recently returned from sub-Saharan Africa presents with hematuria and dysuria. Urinalysis reveals microscopic hematuria and the presence of eggs with a terminal spine on microscopy. Which of the following parasitic infections is most consistent with this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Schistosoma haematobium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Schistosoma haematobium is the only schistosome species with terminal-spined eggs and is classically associated with urinary tract involvement, including hematuria and bladder pathology.

questions.text: In the experiment illustrated in part A of Figure 2, equal volumes of solutions X, Y, and Z are placed into the compartments of the two U-shaped vessels shown. The two compartments of each vessel are separated by semipermeable membranes (i.e., impermeable to ions and large polar molecules). Part B illustrates the fluid distribution across the membranes at equilibration. Assuming complete dissociation, identify each of the solutions shown.

options.label: A
options.text: Solution X: 1 M CaCl₂ | Solution Y: 1 M NaCl | Solution Z: 1 M glucose

options.label: B
options.text: Solution X: 1 M glucose | Solution Y: 1 M NaCl | Solution Z: 1 M CaCl₂

options.label: C
options.text: Solution X: 1 M NaCl | Solution Y: 2 M glucose | Solution Z: 3 M CaCl₂

options.label: D
options.text: Solution X: 2 M NaCl | Solution Y: 1 M NaCl | Solution Z: Pure water

questions.correct_answer: B. Solution X: 1 M glucose | Solution Y: 1 M NaCl | Solution Z: 1 M CaCl₂
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Solution X: 1 M glucose | Solution Y: 1 M NaCl | Solution Z: 1 M CaCl₂

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The movement of water across semipermeable membranes follows osmotic gradients. Ionic solutes like NaCl and CaCl₂ dissociate completely, increasing osmolarity and pulling water into their compartments. Non-dissociating solutes like glucose have lower osmolarity and lose water in osmotic equilibrium. Understanding these principles is essential in clinical settings such as IV fluid administration and electrolyte management.
  • ➤ The movement of water across semipermeable membranes follows osmotic gradients. Ionic solutes like NaCl and CaCl₂ dissociate completely, increasing osmolarity and pulling water into their compartments.
  • ➤ Ionic solutes
  • ➤ Non-dissociating solutes like glucose have lower osmolarity and lose water in osmotic equilibrium. Understanding these principles is essential in clinical settings such as IV fluid administration and electrolyte management.
  • ➤ Non-dissociating solutes

questions.text: Following a carbohydrate-rich meal, a patient’s liver converts excess glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. Under fed-state conditions, what is the primary fate of this metabolite in hepatocytes?

options.label: D
options.text: Metabolism to lactate via anaerobic glycolysis

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Storage as glycogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the fed state, the primary fate of glucose-6-phosphate in the liver is conversion to glycogen, driven by elevated insulin promoting glycogenesis.
  • ➤ In the fed state, the primary fate of glucose-6-phosphate in the liver is conversion to glycogen, driven by elevated insulin promoting glycogenesis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of thyrotoxicosis is found dead in his home. The body temperature is 39°C measured 6 hours post-mortem, while the room temperature is 21°C. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the elevated body temperature after death?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypermetabolic state before death due to thyrotoxicosis

options.label: B
options.text: Hypermetabolic state after death due to thyrotoxicosis

options.label: C
options.text: Early onset of rigor mortis caused by thyrotoxicosis, preventing cooling

questions.correct_answer: A. Hypermetabolic state before death due to thyrotoxicosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypermetabolic state before death due to thyrotoxicosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-mortem elevation of body temperature can result from pre-death hypermetabolic states such as thyrotoxicosis; metabolism ceases after death, and rigor mortis does not prevent heat loss.

questions.text: A 24-year-old elite basketball player complains of progressive anterior knee pain for the past 3 months. The pain worsens with jumping, sprinting, or climbing stairs. On examination, tenderness is elicited precisely at the inferior pole of the patella, and resisted knee extension aggravates the pain. MRI is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Jumper’s knee

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patellar tendon rupture – acute, with loss of function, not gradual pain. Osgood-Schlatter disease – affects tibial tuberosity, common in adolescents, not in adults. Jumper’s knee – chronic tendinopathy due to overuse in jumping sports, with tenderness at the inferior pole of the patella. Hoffa’s fat pad impingement – anterior knee pain with activity, but usually no localized tenderness at the inferior pole of the patella.
  • ➤ Patellar tendon rupture – acute, with loss of function, not gradual pain.
  • ➤ Patellar tendon rupture
  • ➤ Osgood-Schlatter disease – affects tibial tuberosity, common in adolescents, not in adults.
  • ➤ Osgood-Schlatter disease
  • ➤ Jumper’s knee – chronic tendinopathy due to overuse in jumping sports, with tenderness at the inferior pole of the patella.
  • ➤ Jumper’s knee
  • ➤ Hoffa’s fat pad impingement – anterior knee pain with activity, but usually no localized tenderness at the inferior pole of the patella.
  • ➤ Hoffa’s fat pad impingement

questions.text: Based on the given image and child presenting with delayed dentition, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cleidocranial Dysostosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cleidocranial Dysostosis (CCD) is an autosomal dominant skeletal dysplasia affecting the skull, clavicles, and teeth. Key features include hypoplastic or absent clavicles, delayed dentition, supernumerary teeth, and frontal bossing. Diagnosis is clinical but can be confirmed with X-rays showing clavicular hypoplasia and delayed ossification centers.
  • ➤ Cleidocranial Dysostosis (CCD) is an autosomal dominant skeletal dysplasia affecting the skull, clavicles, and teeth.
  • ➤ Key features include hypoplastic or absent clavicles, delayed dentition, supernumerary teeth, and frontal bossing.
  • ➤ Diagnosis is clinical but can be confirmed with X-rays showing clavicular hypoplasia and delayed ossification centers.

questions.text: Match List I (Important Events) with List II (Main Hormone Responsible). List I (Important Events): Initiation of LH surge Preventing luteolysis of corpus luteum Initiation of ovarian cycle Luteal phase defect List II (Main Hormone Responsible): Progesterone hCG FSH Estrogen
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A-4, B-2, C-3, D-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Estrogen triggers the LH surge that induces ovulation. hCG maintains the corpus luteum and prevents luteolysis in early pregnancy. FSH is responsible for follicular recruitment and the initiation of the ovarian cycle. Progesterone deficiency results in luteal phase defects, affecting implantation and pregnancy maintenance.
  • ➤ Estrogen triggers the LH surge that induces ovulation.
  • ➤ hCG maintains the corpus luteum and prevents luteolysis in early pregnancy.
  • ➤ FSH is responsible for follicular recruitment and the initiation of the ovarian cycle.
  • ➤ Progesterone deficiency results in luteal phase defects, affecting implantation and pregnancy maintenance.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is undergoing a cardiovascular stress test. During exercise, his oxygen consumption increases significantly, leading to an enhanced cardiac output and redistribution of blood flow. Which of the following changes is least likely to occur in response to the increased metabolic demand?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased venous return due to muscle pump action

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased splanchnic blood flow due to sympathetic vasoconstriction

options.label: C
options.text: Increased coronary blood flow mediated by local metabolic vasodilation

options.label: D
options.text: Increased total peripheral resistance (TPR) due to widespread vasoconstriction

questions.correct_answer: D. Increased total peripheral resistance (TPR) due to widespread vasoconstriction
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increased total peripheral resistance (TPR) due to widespread vasoconstriction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During exercise, vasodilation in active muscles lowers total peripheral resistance (TPR) despite sympathetic-mediated vasoconstriction in other regions. The primary cardiovascular adaptations include increased cardiac output, redistribution of blood flow, and enhanced oxygen delivery to meet metabolic demand.
  • ➤ During exercise, vasodilation in active muscles lowers total peripheral resistance (TPR) despite sympathetic-mediated vasoconstriction in other regions.
  • ➤ vasodilation in active muscles lowers total peripheral resistance (TPR)
  • ➤ The primary cardiovascular adaptations include increased cardiac output, redistribution of blood flow, and enhanced oxygen delivery to meet metabolic demand.
  • ➤ primary cardiovascular adaptations include increased cardiac output, redistribution of blood flow, and enhanced oxygen delivery

questions.text: The dashed line in the figure illustrates the effect of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Increased blood volume

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Increased blood volume shifts the venous return curve to the right, increasing right atrial pressure and cardiac output. This occurs due to greater circulating volume and increased mean systemic filling pressure, which enhances venous return to the heart.
  • ➤ Increased blood volume shifts the venous return curve to the right, increasing right atrial pressure and cardiac output.
  • ➤ This occurs due to greater circulating volume and increased mean systemic filling pressure, which enhances venous return to the heart.

questions.text: Match List I (Scores) with List II (Condition in which it is used). List I (Scores) Insler score Nugent score Boer Meisel score Ferriman Gallwey score List II (Condition in which it is used) Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis Cervical mucus Hirsutism Alopecia Pregnancy prognosis of tubal infertility
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A-3, B-1, C-6, D-4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Insler score evaluates cervical mucus quality for fertility assessment. Nugent score is a microscopic scoring system for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis . Boer Meisel score assesses endometrial receptivity and pregnancy prognosis in tubal infertility . Ferriman Gallwey score measures hirsutism severity, often used in PCOS evaluation .
  • ➤ Insler score evaluates cervical mucus quality for fertility assessment.
  • ➤ Insler score
  • ➤ cervical mucus quality
  • ➤ Nugent score is a microscopic scoring system for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis .
  • ➤ Nugent score
  • ➤ microscopic scoring system for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis
  • ➤ Boer Meisel score assesses endometrial receptivity and pregnancy prognosis in tubal infertility .
  • ➤ Boer Meisel score
  • ➤ endometrial receptivity and pregnancy prognosis in tubal infertility
  • ➤ Ferriman Gallwey score measures hirsutism severity, often used in PCOS evaluation .
  • ➤ Ferriman Gallwey score
  • ➤ hirsutism severity, often used in PCOS evaluation

questions.text: Match the Following: Supraglottic Airway Devices Column A (Devices) LMA Supreme LMA Proseal LMA Fastrach Ambu AURA40 Column B (Features) A. First-generation device B. Special LMA C. Single-use second-generation device D. Multiple-use second-generation device
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ LMA Supreme → Single-use second-generation device LMA Proseal → Multiple-use second-generation device LMA Fastrach → Special LMA designed for intubation Ambu AURA40 → First-generation device
  • ➤ LMA Supreme → Single-use second-generation device
  • ➤ LMA Proseal → Multiple-use second-generation device
  • ➤ LMA Fastrach → Special LMA designed for intubation
  • ➤ Ambu AURA40 → First-generation device

questions.text: A 55-year-old man admitted to the ICU for septic shock on vasopressor support suddenly develops hypotension and altered sensorium. His extremities are cold and central venous pressure is elevated. POCUS findings are shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Massive pulmonary embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In ICU patients with obstructive shock and POCUS showing RV overload, massive pulmonary embolism must be suspected.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is evaluated for fatigue, low-grade fever, joint pain, and a newly detected positive anti-histone antibody on serologic testing. His symptoms began several weeks after starting a new medication. He has no known autoimmune history. Among the drugs listed below, which is least likely to be responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Amphetamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydralazine, isoniazid, and procainamide are commonly associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus, which is often confirmed by the presence of anti-histone antibodies. Amphetamine is not linked to this condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who has been infertile for 3 years presents to the clinic. She reports frequent, painful periods with dysmenorrhea, which is most severe on the third day of menstruation. She also complains of deep dyspareunia. Her Day 21 progesterone level is 32 nmol/L, and her partner’s semen analysis is normal. Which of the following investigations should be performed next?

options.label: D
options.text: Transvaginal ultrasound scan for follicular tracking

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Diagnostic Laparoscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endometriosis should be suspected in women with infertility, dysmenorrhea, and deep dyspareunia. Diagnostic Laparoscopy with dye test is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis and assessing tubal patency. HSG is useful for tubal assessment but does not detect peritoneal disease. A normal Day 21 progesterone level confirms ovulation, ruling out anovulatory causes of infertility.
  • ➤ Endometriosis should be suspected in women with infertility, dysmenorrhea, and deep dyspareunia.
  • ➤ Diagnostic Laparoscopy with dye test is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis and assessing tubal patency.
  • ➤ HSG is useful for tubal assessment but does not detect peritoneal disease.
  • ➤ A normal Day 21 progesterone level confirms ovulation, ruling out anovulatory causes of infertility.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with acute diarrhea, signs of dehydration, and altered electrolytes. Laboratory investigations reveal Na+ 125 mEq/L, K+ 3 mEq/L, HCO₃⁻ 16 mEq/L, and pH 7.23.Which of the following IV fluids should be administered?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Normal saline (0.9% NaCl)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Normal saline (0.9% NaCl) is the IV fluid of choice for dehydration with hyponatremia and metabolic acidosis. Avoid hypotonic fluids (e.g., N/3 saline, dextrose-containing solutions) in dehydration to prevent further sodium imbalance. 3% saline is reserved for severe symptomatic hyponatremia (e.g., seizures), not for mild to moderate cases.
  • ➤ Normal saline (0.9% NaCl) is the IV fluid of choice for dehydration with hyponatremia and metabolic acidosis.
  • ➤ Normal saline (0.9% NaCl) is the IV fluid of choice for dehydration with hyponatremia and metabolic acidosis.
  • ➤ Avoid hypotonic fluids (e.g., N/3 saline, dextrose-containing solutions) in dehydration to prevent further sodium imbalance.
  • ➤ Avoid hypotonic fluids (e.g., N/3 saline, dextrose-containing solutions) in dehydration
  • ➤ 3% saline is reserved for severe symptomatic hyponatremia (e.g., seizures), not for mild to moderate cases.
  • ➤ 3% saline is reserved for severe symptomatic hyponatremia (e.g., seizures), not for mild to moderate cases.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with anterior neck pain, low-grade fever, and fatigue for the past week. She reports that the pain radiates to her jaw and worsens with swallowing. On examination, the thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and exquisitely tender to palpation. Labs show: Elevated free T4 Suppressed TSH Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) Low radioactive iodine uptake on scan Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subacute granulomatous (de Quervain) thyroiditis is a self-limited, painful thyroid condition that follows viral illness. It causes transient thyrotoxicosis with low radioactive iodine uptake and is characterized by granulomatous inflammation with giant cells.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with chronic diarrhea, bloating, and fatigue. Her labs show iron-deficiency anemia and mildly elevated liver enzymes. Serologic testing reveals IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-tTG). Duodenal biopsy is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Celiac disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Celiac disease is diagnosed by IgA (or IgG) antibodies against tTG, endomysium, or gliadin, and confirmed by duodenal biopsy showing villous flattening, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes. The duodenum is most affected, with jejunum and ileum less involved.
  • ➤ Celiac disease is diagnosed by IgA (or IgG) antibodies against tTG, endomysium, or gliadin, and confirmed by duodenal biopsy showing villous flattening, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes.
  • ➤ The duodenum is most affected, with jejunum and ileum less involved.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Raloxifene is incorrect? Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that acts as an estrogen agonist on bone. It increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma similar to tamoxifen. Raloxifene reduces vertebral fracture risk but has no proven benefit for hip fracture prevention. It acts as an estrogen antagonist on breast and uterine tissue. Raloxifene is associated with an increased risk of venous thromboembolism.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Only statement 2 is incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator that acts as an estrogen agonist on bone and antagonist on breast and endometrium. Unlike tamoxifen, it does not increase the risk of endometrial cancer. It is associated with an increased risk of venous thromboembolism.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, G2P2, undergoes a normal vaginal delivery but develops severe postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) despite an intact placenta. The uterus is soft and boggy, indicating uterine atony. Uterine massage and oxytocin administration fail to control the bleeding. Arrange the following steps in the correct order for managing atonic PPH not responding to uterine massage: Oxytocin infusion Ligation of the uterine artery B-Lynch compression suture Tamponade using a hydrostatic balloon catheter
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1 - 4 - 3 - 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage. Stepwise management of PPH: Medical management with oxytocics Mechanical methods including intra uterine balloon tamponade Compression sutures (B-Lynch) Stepwise devascularization (uterine artery, utero-ovarian and ant div of internal iliac) Early intervention is crucial to prevent maternal morbidity and mortality .
  • ➤ Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage.
  • ➤ Stepwise management of PPH: Medical management with oxytocics Mechanical methods including intra uterine balloon tamponade Compression sutures (B-Lynch) Stepwise devascularization (uterine artery, utero-ovarian and ant div of internal iliac)
  • ➤ Stepwise management of PPH:
  • ➤ Medical management with oxytocics Mechanical methods including intra uterine balloon tamponade Compression sutures (B-Lynch) Stepwise devascularization (uterine artery, utero-ovarian and ant div of internal iliac)
  • ➤ Medical management with oxytocics
  • ➤ Mechanical methods including intra uterine balloon tamponade
  • ➤ Compression sutures (B-Lynch)
  • ➤ Stepwise devascularization (uterine artery, utero-ovarian and ant div of internal iliac)
  • ➤ Early intervention is crucial to prevent maternal morbidity and mortality .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Ringertz tumor are true? It is a benign neoplasm arising from the Schneiderian membrane of the nose and paranasal sinuses. The most common site of origin is the lateral nasal wall near the middle meatus. It is usually bilateral and frequently associated with allergic rhinitis. The gold standard treatment is medial maxillectomy, preferably via an endoscopic approach. Radiotherapy is the primary treatment of choice to prevent recurrence. Up to 15% of cases may undergo malignant transformation, most commonly into squamous cell carcinoma.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 4, 6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inverted papilloma (Ringertz tumor) is a benign but locally aggressive sinonasal tumor. Unilateral nasal obstruction with epistaxis is a key symptom. Endoscopic medial maxillectomy is the preferred treatment due to high recurrence rates and malignant potential. Radiotherapy is avoided as it may lead to malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).
  • ➤ Inverted papilloma (Ringertz tumor) is a benign but locally aggressive sinonasal tumor.
  • ➤ Unilateral nasal obstruction with epistaxis is a key symptom.
  • ➤ Endoscopic medial maxillectomy is the preferred treatment due to high recurrence rates and malignant potential.
  • ➤ Radiotherapy is avoided as it may lead to malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with localized prostate cancer is scheduled for robot-assisted radical prostatectomy (RARP) using a da Vinci surgical system. The surgical team discusses the advantages, limitations, and technical considerations of robotic surgery. Which of the following statements about robotic surgery is true? Robotic-assisted surgery eliminates the need for pneumoperitoneum, making it safer for patients with cardiopulmonary compromise. The master-slave telemanipulation system allows the surgeon to control robotic arms with enhanced precision and motion scaling. Robotic surgery provides 3D high-definition vision, wristed instruments with 7 degrees of freedom, and tremor filtration. Haptic feedback is a major advantage of current robotic systems, allowing the surgeon to feel tissue resistance. Robotic surgery is associated with shorter hospital stays, less blood loss, and faster recovery compared to open surgery.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2, 3, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Robotic surgery enhances precision, dexterity, and visualization but still requires pneumoperitoneum . Lack of haptic feedback is a major limitation, requiring reliance on visual cues . Advantages include 3D vision, motion scaling, tremor filtration, and shorter recovery times .
  • ➤ Robotic surgery enhances precision, dexterity, and visualization but still requires pneumoperitoneum .
  • ➤ Robotic surgery enhances precision, dexterity, and visualization
  • ➤ pneumoperitoneum
  • ➤ Lack of haptic feedback is a major limitation, requiring reliance on visual cues .
  • ➤ Lack of haptic feedback
  • ➤ visual cues
  • ➤ Advantages include 3D vision, motion scaling, tremor filtration, and shorter recovery times .
  • ➤ Advantages
  • ➤ 3D vision, motion scaling, tremor filtration, and shorter recovery times

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with newly diagnosed schizophrenia presents for pharmacologic management. He has a history of obesity, type 2 diabetes, and a strong family history of coronary artery disease. The physician chooses an antipsychotic with low risk of weight gain and minimal metabolic side effects. However, the medication requires caution due to its potential to prolong the QT interval. Which of the following agents was most likely prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ziprasidone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ziprasidone is an atypical antipsychotic with minimal metabolic side effects, making it suitable for patients at risk for weight gain and diabetes. However, its use is limited by the risk of QT interval prolongation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a periampullary carcinoma is scheduled for a Pancreaticoduodenectomy. Which of the following represents the correct steps in the procedure?

options.label: A

questions.text: In a study comparing the recovery rates of two different rehabilitation programs for stroke patients, patients were randomly assigned to one of two groups. Which test is best suited to compare the ordinal scale outcomes between these two independent groups?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Wilcoxon rank-sum test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When conducting studies with two independent groups where data are ordinal or not normally distributed, the Wilcoxon rank-sum test provides a reliable method for assessing differences. It avoids the assumptions of normality required by parametric tests and is more powerful than other non-parametric alternatives for independent samples.

questions.text: A researcher studying amino acid metabolism isolates an enzyme that can function in both oxidative deamination and reductive amination reactions. He observes that the enzyme is versatile in electron transfer, as it can utilize both NAD⁺ and NADP⁺ as cofactors depending on cellular needs. Which of the following enzymes exhibits this cofactor flexibility?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glutamate dehydrogenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glutamate dehydrogenase is the only enzyme among the options that can use both NAD⁺ and NADP⁺ as cofactors, depending on the metabolic context.

Ans. C) Fistula-in-ano

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus and well-controlled hypertension is evaluated for elevated lipid levels. His fasting lipid profile shows: Total cholesterol: 205 mg/dL LDL-C: 100 mg/dL HDL-C: 42 mg/dL Triglycerides: 690 mg/dL He has no history of pancreatitis but reports intermittent abdominal discomfort. He is currently taking metformin and lisinopril. Which of the following medications is most appropriate to reduce this patient’s triglyceride level and prevent pancreatitis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fenofibrate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fenofibrate is the drug of choice for patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia (>500 mg/dL) to reduce the risk of acute pancreatitis. It works by activating PPAR-α to enhance triglyceride metabolism.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with sudden right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. He has no history of hypertension, diabetes, or smoking. Examination shows right hemiparesis and expressive aphasia. MRI of the brain is shown. Echocardiography reveals a patent foramen ovale (PFO). No atherosclerotic disease is found on vascular imaging. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Antiplatelet therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ PFO closure is recommended only in patients <60 years with cryptogenic embolic stroke and no alternate cause; antiplatelet therapy is standard in older patients.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue and early satiety. Physical examination reveals massive splenomegaly, but no lymphadenopathy. CBC shows pancytopenia. Bone marrow aspiration results in a dry tap. A peripheral smear demonstrates lymphocytes with abundant pale cytoplasm and fine, hair-like cytoplasmic projections. The neoplastic cells are positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hairy Cell Leukemia (HCL)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hairy Cell Leukemia is a B-cell malignancy characterized by cytoplasmic projections, TRAP positivity, splenomegaly, dry tap on marrow aspiration, and typically no lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the effects of two different enzyme inhibitors, A and B, on the activity of an enzyme involved in a metabolic pathway. The researcher observes the following: Inhibitor A increases the Km (Michaelis constant) of the enzyme without affecting the Vmax (maximum velocity). Inhibitor B decreases the Vmax without changing the Km. Based on these observations, the researcher classifies the types of inhibition. What is the most likely classification of Inhibitor A and Inhibitor B?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Competitive and non-competitive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inhibitor A: Competitive (increases Km, no effect on Vmax) Inhibitor B: Non-competitive (decreases Vmax, no effect on Km)

  • ➤ Inhibitor A:
  • ➤ Inhibitor B: Non-competitive (decreases Vmax, no effect on Km)
  • ➤ Inhibitor B:

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought for a routine pediatric check-up. The pediatrician assesses his growth, dentition, and motor milestones. Which of the following statements are true for a 2-year-old child? Statements: The child's weight is four times that of birth weight. The child can ride a tricycle independently. The child climbs up and down stairs with alternating steps. Both upper and lower canines have erupted. The ossification center for the head of the radius appears.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At 2 years, weight is approximately 4 times the birth weight. Canines usually erupt between 16–20 months, so they are present at 2 years. Tricycle riding (3 years) and climbing stairs with alternating steps (4 years) occur later. Ossification of the radial head occurs between 3–4 years.
  • ➤ At 2 years, weight is approximately 4 times the birth weight.
  • ➤ Canines usually erupt between 16–20 months, so they are present at 2 years.
  • ➤ Tricycle riding (3 years) and climbing stairs with alternating steps (4 years) occur later.
  • ➤ Ossification of the radial head occurs between 3–4 years.

questions.text: Craigie’s tube method is used in the microbiology lab to assess which of the following characteristics?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Motile and nonmotile strains

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Craigie’s tube method distinguishes motile from nonmotile bacterial strains by observing their ability to spread from a capillary tube into surrounding semi-solid agar.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not seen by the procedure shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Middle meatus

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding drugs with high first-pass metabolism is/are correct? Lignocaine is ineffective orally due to extensive hepatic metabolism after absorption. Propranolol undergoes significant first-pass metabolism, leading to reduced oral bioavailability. Glyceryl trinitrate is given sublingually to bypass first-pass metabolism and achieve rapid action. Drugs with high first-pass metabolism are always preferred orally due to longer duration of action. High first-pass effect means the drug reaches the systemic circulation unchanged in high concentration.
questions.correct_answer: A. Only statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Only statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Drugs with high first-pass metabolism, such as lignocaine, propranolol, and nitroglycerin, undergo significant hepatic breakdown after oral administration. Alternate routes (e.g., IV or sublingual) are often used to bypass the liver and improve bioavailability.

questions.text: In a municipal effort to reduce environmental impacts associated with waste management, public health officials evaluate various disposal methods. Considering the need to minimize groundwater contamination while acknowledging potential negative externalities, which waste disposal method should be prioritized despite its high energy use and air pollution concerns?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Incineration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Incineration, while energy-intensive and potentially polluting, effectively prevents groundwater contamination from waste disposal, making it a crucial option in areas where groundwater protection is a priority. Advanced emission controls are necessary to mitigate its environmental impact on air quality.
  • ➤ Incineration, while energy-intensive and potentially polluting, effectively prevents groundwater contamination from waste disposal, making it a crucial option in areas where groundwater protection is a priority.
  • ➤ Advanced emission controls are necessary to mitigate its environmental impact on air quality.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is diagnosed with varicella. Her pregnant aunt is concerned about the risk of exposure. She asks when she can safely meet the child. When is the earliest that the child can meet her pregnant aunt?

options.label: C
options.text: After the aunt has taken the varicella vaccine

options.label: D
options.text: After the delivery of the baby

questions.correct_answer: A. When the lesions have crusted
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) When the lesions have crusted

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Varicella is contagious from 1–2 days before rash onset until all lesions crust over. Pregnant women are at high risk of severe varicella infection and fetal complications. Isolation should continue until the lesions are completely crusted. Post-exposure prophylaxis (VZIG or vaccination) may be considered in high-risk individuals.
  • ➤ Varicella is contagious from 1–2 days before rash onset until all lesions crust over.
  • ➤ Pregnant women are at high risk of severe varicella infection and fetal complications.
  • ➤ Isolation should continue until the lesions are completely crusted.
  • ➤ Post-exposure prophylaxis (VZIG or vaccination) may be considered in high-risk individuals.

This knowledge is essential for effectively prioritizing and deploying medical and emergency resources in the aftermath of a disaster.

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to generalized seizures, developmental delay, and decreased activity. Examination reveals hypopigmented skin, grayish hair, and a mousy body odor. Urine testing reveals elevated phenylalanine levels. Further evaluation suggests a rare variant of phenylketonuria (PKU) due to a defect unrelated to the primary enzyme. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dihydropterin reductase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dihydropterin reductase deficiency causes a rare variant of PKU by impairing BH4 regeneration, leading to functional loss of phenylalanine hydroxylase despite normal enzyme structure.

questions.text: Which of the following bacterial toxins increases adenylate cyclase activity via G-protein coupled activation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cholera toxin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholera toxin increases intracellular cAMP by ADP-ribosylating Gs proteins, activating adenylate cyclase via a G-protein coupled mechanism—leading to severe secretory diarrhea.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient on medical therapy for chronic open-angle glaucoma presents for follow-up after routine tonometry shows persistently elevated intraocular pressure. The ophthalmic examination is otherwise stable. To enhance aqueous humor outflow through the uveoscleral pathway, the current medication regimen is adjusted. Which of the following drugs most specifically facilitates this mechanism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Latanoprost

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Latanoprost lowers intraocular pressure in glaucoma patients by enhancing uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor. It is a prostaglandin analog and considered first-line in the chronic management of open-angle glaucoma.

  • ➤ It is a prostaglandin analog and considered first-line in the chronic management of open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: In the treatment of salicylate poisoning, why is alkaline diuresis commonly employed?

options.label: A
options.text: Alkaline diuresis increases the renal elimination of salicylate by enhancing its ionization, making it less reabsorbed.

options.label: B
options.text: Alkaline diuresis neutralizes the acidic environment in the stomach, reducing salicylate absorption.

options.label: C
options.text: Alkaline diuresis increases the metabolic conversion of salicylate into a non-toxic form.

options.label: D
options.text: Alkaline diuresis helps to reverse the respiratory alkalosis caused by salicylate toxicity.

questions.correct_answer: A. Alkaline diuresis increases the renal elimination of salicylate by enhancing its ionization, making it less reabsorbed.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Alkaline diuresis increases the renal elimination of salicylate by enhancing its ionization, making it less reabsorbed.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alkaline diuresis enhances the renal excretion of salicylates by increasing their ionization in urine, thus reducing reabsorption and aiding in detoxification.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with weight loss, heat intolerance, palpitations, and tremors. Examination shows a diffusely enlarged thyroid with bruit and exophthalmos. Lab evaluation reveals suppressed TSH and elevated T3 and T4. Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins are positive. She is scheduled for radioactive iodine ablation (RAIA) therapy. What should be the next appropriate step before initiating RAIA?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Start methimazole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methimazole is initiated before RAIA in hyperthyroid patients to prevent thyroid storm by achieving a euthyroid state.

questions.text: Match the following Rickettsial species with their associated diseases: Which of the following is the correct match?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: In an urban public health campaign focused on minimizing Typhoid Fever incidence, which metric would be most useful for evaluating the initiative's success?

options.label: A
options.text: Annual count of hospital admissions related to Typhoid Fever.

options.label: B
options.text: Yearly community survey assessing water usage and sanitation habits.

options.label: C
options.text: Analysis of antibiotic resistance trends in identified Typhoid Fever cases.

options.label: D
options.text: Routine screening of food handlers for Typhoid carriers.

questions.correct_answer: B. Yearly community survey assessing water usage and sanitation habits.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Yearly community survey assessing water usage and sanitation habits.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For public health initiatives aimed at controlling diseases like Typhoid Fever, which is primarily transmitted through contaminated water, the most effective evaluation method focuses on monitoring and improving environmental and sanitary conditions.   • ➤ For public health initiatives aimed at controlling diseases like Typhoid Fever, which is primarily transmitted through contaminated water, the most effective evaluation method focuses on monitoring and improving environmental and sanitary conditions.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a 10-year history of ulcerative colitis presents with fatigue and pruritus. Liver function tests reveal markedly elevated alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT), with near-normal bilirubin and aminotransferases. MRCP is done and it is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Primary sclerosing cholangitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ PSC should be suspected in IBD patients with cholestatic LFTs and confirmed by MRCP showing multifocal strictures.

questions.text: Match List I (Adult Structures) with List II (Corresponding Embryonic Origin). List I (Adult Structures) Gartner’s duct Round ligament Lower vagina Clitoris List II (Embryonic Origin) Mesonephric duct Gubernaculum Genital ridge Genital tubercle Müllerian duct Urogenital sinus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A-1, B-2, C-6, D-4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gartner’s duct is a remnant of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct in females. The round ligament originates from the gubernaculum, aiding uterine support. The lower vagina forms from the urogenital sinus, while the upper part is from the Müllerian duct. The genital tubercle differentiates into the clitoris in females and the penis in males.
  • ➤ Gartner’s duct is a remnant of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct in females.
  • ➤ The round ligament originates from the gubernaculum, aiding uterine support.
  • ➤ The lower vagina forms from the urogenital sinus, while the upper part is from the Müllerian duct.
  • ➤ The genital tubercle differentiates into the clitoris in females and the penis in males.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with no known past medical history suddenly collapses while jogging. He is pronounced dead at the scene. Family history reveals that his father also died suddenly in his 30s. Autopsy reveals a markedly thickened interventricular septum, and histologic examination of the myocardium is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a genetic myocardial disorder characterized by asymmetric septal hypertrophy, myofiber disarray, and interstitial fibrosis. It is a common cause of sudden cardiac death in young individuals, particularly during exertion.

questions.text: Which of the following are branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery? Superior gluteal artery Inferior gluteal artery Superior vesical artery Middle rectal artery Inferior vesical artery Vaginal artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2, 3, 4, 5, 6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The internal iliac artery supplies most of the pelvic structures and divides into anterior and posterior divisions. The anterior division supplies pelvic organs (bladder, rectum, reproductive structures) and gluteal/perineal regions. The posterior division mainly supplies the pelvic walls and gluteal muscles. The superior gluteal artery is a posterior division branch, while the inferior gluteal artery is from the anterior division.
  • ➤ The internal iliac artery supplies most of the pelvic structures and divides into anterior and posterior divisions.
  • ➤ The anterior division supplies pelvic organs (bladder, rectum, reproductive structures) and gluteal/perineal regions.
  • ➤ The posterior division mainly supplies the pelvic walls and gluteal muscles.
  • ➤ The superior gluteal artery is a posterior division branch, while the inferior gluteal artery is from the anterior division.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man who recently returned from rural India presents with a 2-month history of intermittent fever, weight loss, and abdominal fullness. On physical examination, he has hepatosplenomegaly and pallor. Laboratory tests reveal pancytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy shows macrophages filled with amastigotes. What is the most appropriate first-line pharmacologic treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Amphotericin B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) should be suspected in patients with prolonged fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia returning from endemic areas like rural India. The first-line treatment is liposomal Amphotericin B.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of bronchial asthma is prescribed a tablet formulation of Salbutamol Sulphate. The packaging label includes the abbreviation “IP” next to the drug name, as shown in the image. What does “IP” most accurately indicate in this context?

options.label: C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The abbreviation “IP” on a drug label indicates that the formulation complies with the standards set by the Indian Pharmacopoeia, ensuring quality, identity, and purity of the pharmaceutical product.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female visits the clinic for cervical cancer prevention counseling. She is advised to receive the nonavalent HPV vaccine, which provides protection against multiple high-risk Human Papillomavirus (HPV) strains associated with cervical, vulvar, vaginal, and anal cancers, as well as genital warts. Which of the following HPV strains are covered by the nonavalent HPV vaccine?
questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HPV vaccination is essential for preventing cervical and anogenital cancers and genital warts. The nonavalent HPV vaccine (Gardasil-9) covers 9 HPV types (16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58, 6, and 11). Cervarix is effective against 16 and 18 Gardasil and Cervavac are effective against 6,11,16 and 18 HPV 16 and 18 are the most oncogenic types, responsible for the majority of cervical cancer cases.
  • ➤ HPV vaccination is essential for preventing cervical and anogenital cancers and genital warts.
  • ➤ The nonavalent HPV vaccine (Gardasil-9) covers 9 HPV types (16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58, 6, and 11).
  • ➤ Cervarix is effective against 16 and 18
  • ➤ Gardasil and Cervavac are effective against 6,11,16 and 18
  • ➤ HPV 16 and 18 are the most oncogenic types, responsible for the majority of cervical cancer cases.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis from the images shown below?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with intermittent episodes of right upper abdominal pain. On physical examination, her abdomen is normal. A routine abdominal ultrasound reveals multiple tiny gallbladder calculi. Laboratory investigations show a direct bilirubin level of 2.4 mg% and elevated alkaline phosphatase levels. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) MRCP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with suspected choledocholithiasis (deranged liver function tests and cholelithiasis), MRCP is the preferred non-invasive diagnostic test to evaluate the biliary tree for CBD stones. Invasive procedures like ERCP are reserved for confirmed diagnoses or therapeutic interventions.

questions.text: A public health official is assessing the effectiveness of a salt iodization program in a rural community. Which indicator would be most appropriate for early detection of changes in the community's iodine status?

options.label: A
options.text: Total Goitre Rate (TGR) in children aged 6-12 years

options.label: B
options.text: Median urinary iodine excretion levels in pregnant women

options.label: C
options.text: Proportion of households using adequately iodized salt

questions.correct_answer: B. Median urinary iodine excretion levels in pregnant women
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Median urinary iodine excretion levels in pregnant women

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the context of monitoring the effectiveness of iodine supplementation programs, median urinary iodine excretion levels in pregnant women provide a quick and reliable measure of current iodine status, crucial for early intervention and adjustment of public health strategies. This indicator helps public health officials to act swiftly in adjusting iodization levels to prevent iodine deficiency disorders in the community.
  • ➤ In the context of monitoring the effectiveness of iodine supplementation programs, median urinary iodine excretion levels in pregnant women provide a quick and reliable measure of current iodine status, crucial for early intervention and adjustment of public health strategies.

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn is admitted to the NICU with progressive lethargy, rapid breathing, and poor feeding. Physical examination reveals hypothermia and signs of cerebral edema. Labs show a markedly low blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and elevated plasma ammonia. Urinalysis is notable for increased orotic acid and glutamine levels, with no evidence of hypoglycemia. The infant develops coma shortly after admission. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is the most likely cause of this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mitochondrial ornithine transcarbamoylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency is a mitochondrial enzyme defect that leads to neonatal hyperammonemia, low BUN, elevated orotic acid, and coma due to impaired urea cycle function.

questions.text: A 42-year-old farmer presents with fever, weight loss, and nonproductive cough. Chest imaging reveals patchy pulmonary infiltrates. A fungal infection is suspected. A biopsy sample cultured at different temperatures reveals yeast cells at 37°C and mold (hyphal) forms at 25°C. Which of the following organisms most likely exhibits this temperature-dependent morphological change?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Histoplasma capsulatum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus that exists in mold form at 25°C and yeast form at 37°C. This thermal dimorphism is critical for its pathogenicity and helps differentiate it from other fungi

questions.text: A 25-year-old male reports persistent posterior knee discomfort and localized swelling over the past two weeks. He denies any trauma or systemic symptoms. MRI of the knee is given below. Based on this imaging and clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Baker’s cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Baker’s cyst presents as a fluid-filled lesion in the popliteal fossa, typically located between the medial gastrocnemius and semimembranosus tendon, and is best visualized on MRI.

questions.text: In managing a screening program for a newly emerging viral infection in a rural area with limited healthcare resources, the public health team faces a dilemma in test selection due to the economic burden of false positives. Given the population's low disease prevalence and the high cost of follow-up confirmatory tests, which testing strategy should the team employ to ensure the highest diagnostic accuracy while minimizing unnecessary follow-ups?

options.label: A
options.text: Initiate screening with a high-sensitivity test, followed by a high-specificity test only for those who test positive.

options.label: B
options.text: Simultaneously apply two high-sensitivity tests to all individuals, confirming disease only if both tests are positive.

options.label: C
options.text: Implement a single high-specificity test and retest only those who test positive with another high-specificity test.

options.label: D
options.text: Deploy a single high-sensitivity test and accept its results without subsequent confirmation to maximize resource efficiency.

questions.correct_answer: A. Initiate screening with a high-sensitivity test, followed by a high-specificity test only for those who test positive.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Initiate screening with a high-sensitivity test, followed by a high-specificity test only for those who test positive.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In public health screening, especially for low-prevalence conditions, strategically sequencing tests—starting with a high-sensitivity test followed by a high-specificity test for positives—effectively enhances diagnostic accuracy while minimizing the economic and logistical burdens of false positives. This approach optimizes the use of resources in constrained settings and ensures that only the most likely positive cases undergo expensive and resource-intensive confirmatory testing.
  • ➤ In public health screening, especially for low-prevalence conditions, strategically sequencing tests—starting with a high-sensitivity test followed by a high-specificity test for positives—effectively enhances diagnostic accuracy while minimizing the economic and logistical burdens of false positives.
  • ➤ This approach optimizes the use of resources in constrained settings and ensures that only the most likely positive cases undergo expensive and resource-intensive confirmatory testing.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man is evaluated for changes in appearance and metabolism. He reports that over the last year he has noticed his shoes and gloves no longer fit, and others have commented on his coarsened facial features. He also reports excessive sweating and has been recently diagnosed with impaired glucose tolerance. On examination, enlargement of the hands, feet, and jaw (chin protrusion) is observed. MRI reveals a pituitary macroadenoma. Which of the following medications acts as a growth hormone receptor antagonist and is appropriate for the treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pegvisomant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used in the treatment of acromegaly to reduce IGF-1 levels by blocking peripheral GH signaling.
